description: Go all the way in back of the farmers market at the Ferry building and look for the yellow Primavera sign, hand some cash over and be prepared to have some of the best chilaquiles EVER! Yes, its cash only and a wait but friends, it's worth it. I just wish I would have been a touch hungrier to snarf down the entire plate. A number of people were getting the strawberry lemonade as well but I had to have my coffee while enjoying breakfast.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
I've been coming to the farmer's market at the Ferry Building for three years and I always make a stop at Primavera for their amazing agua frescas and lemonades. Their food is great but for me the drinks are stand-out quality because they're so fresh. The strawberry lime lemonade has a puree like consistency because they truly use strawberries in their drinks. It's the perfect combo of sweet and tart! The pineapple cucumber agua fresca is also soooo tasty and refreshing, especially on the hot summer days at the farmer's market.

Grab one of their drinks and sip on it while enjoying the view of the Bay Bridge and water right in front of the stand
author: Megan K.

description:
Not worth the hype.  

There's nothing bad about the food here but there's nothing particularly great about it either, just very middle of the road.  Everything was fresh and well presented but the flavor was underwhelming.  We had the chilaquiles and the chips, sauce, beans, queso were all just meh.

This place is definitely benefiting from tourist skew in terms of ratings.  I'd pass but if you're in the mood to wait in line for 10 mins and then wait another 15 more for so-so Mexican, then have at it!
author: Saminda W.

description:
Primavera was a prima facie case of very disappointed bundled in chilaquiles form. Each triangle of corn totopos, holding a TOTOlly sad POSition in the ranks of the honorable Californian chilaquiles - in form, texture and taste.  

The expectation was here:

(you unfortunately can't see how high the mark is because the Yelp word parameters will not allow it to appear)

The execution was here:

(you unfortunately can't see a mark because it's miscroscopic and not visible to the naked human eye)

'What happened?' may be the response of the slew of elite 5 star reviews and ultra positive feedback - 'Maybe you tried the stand on a bad day?' 'Did you have a little too much taquila to recall the quile-chile?' Why, no, that would've made it all the more tasty.  I digress... back to the meat and potatoes. Or to the beans and totopos. 

(1) Texture - The texture was so off balance, each totopos soggy, with no slight crunch coming through - no strength to endure the mole that was left on it for too long before the handover from pan to table. And the less than ideal texture was a theme that resonated across the plate - the beans tasting as if they were refried beans right out of a can. I yearned for the slight crunch of the chilaquiles against the salsa/mole, and for grandma's stewed beans cooked with the rustic homemade feel.  All of those components were missing. 

(2) Flavor - the chilaquiles certainly got me to question the OR in flavOR.  This wasn't the flavor profile I was expecting. It was something else - or nothing. A bland form of salsa/mole. I was missing the expected flavor burst so characteristic of Mexican mole. Where did the CHILE in the CHILEquiles go? The ancho, pasilla, mulato and chipotle? Where was the crushed black pepper, the achiote, cumin, cloves, anise, tomatoes, tomatillos, garlic, sesame seeds, and herbs?  Where did the flavor go? 

(3) Portion - I get it - there's high rent in SF to account for. But isn't it already accounted for in the extra SF vendor fee that is imposed? In addition to the general issues with texture and taste, I was further disappointed by the amount - or lack of amount - of substance and food delivered. I could count 4 pieces (note, not slices) of square and triangular avocados on my plate. With an amount of totopos less than 10.  Maybe the beans are purposefully mashed to prevent one from noticing the 15-20 beans that would've been on the plate but for the mashing to disguise?

(4) Overall performance and delivery - Bursting with desire to try the chilequiles, and filled with anticipation backed by raving reviews, I waited around 25 minutes in line and another 6-8 minutes thereafter for the chilaquiles to be prepared. 30 plus minutes of my life I will never get back. Please do not make the same mistake as me. Or do, but do so knowing that this is not that SoCal San Diegan variant of chilequiles, but a foreign, neutral variant. 

As a recourse I thought... maybe I should try another dish? Maybe I should try the fish taco that came highly recommended by the Primavera rep? But from the soggy tortilla to the overly battered and oily fish to the totally lacking flavors and salsa, this only reconfirmed my earlier findings. I tried so much to like this place that is highly regarded by many.  But I guess this is one of those times the old adage is true - I would not jump off a bridge if others were to. 

Primavera, Ima so disappointed and vera much wish I could post a more hopeful and positive review.  Please hear my plea to do justice to the noble and delicious chilaquiles dish that brings honor to California and its resident Californians.
author: Vivienne K.

description: Had chilliquilles.  They were very fresh and good.  I'd get food here again. It was a little crowded.
author: Michael E.

description:
~CASH ONLY~

Ohhhhh chilaquiles ($10). So much flavor covering crispy tortilla chips. When you try to combine everything on the plate to one bite, it's a delicious explosion. Eggs were wonderfully buttery and smooth. All the condiments complimented the dish nicely. I am usually not a fan of beans, but I loooved the refried beans on the plate. 

Also, you have a nice view of the Bay Bridge while enjoying your breakfast/brunch.
author: Cindy D.

description:
#bestchilaquilesEVA 
This belated review was prompted by my many recent chilaquile disappointments in the southland.  Anyone who likes to EAT and finds themselves in San Francisco MUST visit the Ferry Building Farmers Market for a weekend walking extravaganza of eating FTW!  This market houses one of my absolute FAVE chilaquiles Of ALL TIME!  These thick corn tortillas got authentic CRUNCH (no sad soggy chips here)! The fresh ingredients including cilantro, onion, crema, avocado and cojita with the eggs, beans and salsa roja all come together in a TO DIE FOR party in your mouth!  I literally day dream about this meal, no joke!  Grab a plate and eat while enjoying the beautiful view of the bay bridge.  We're talking go alone just to eat this meal with total strangers on the benches GOOD!  Aka Hella Good!
author: Tracy C.

description:
Hands down my favorite thing at the Ferry Place market. Head straight out back to get the best Mexican breakfast! Obsessed with the chilaquiles, refried beans and chips that are sturdy enough to stand up to the heavy sauce. 

Must eat on a Saturday morning in SF.
author: Leila K.

description:
Primavera sells mexican eats quickly. has lots of backup associates.

menu: Chilaquiles, Tacos   breakfast burrito?, Tamale Plate, pork/chicken tamale

eats: niman ranch tacos (2/10)
--citrus spiced, marinated pork, avocado, purple onion, cilantro, tomato sauce?..
-lots of chucky meat in soft tacos
-needed more sauce.
author: Victor G.

description: So chips cooked in salsa might be my new favorite thing. For now, I'll have to obsess over how the chips were entirely coated yet still crunchy. My friend told me these are the best chilaquiles and I will have to believe him. Yum!
author: Kenny N.

description:
Ignore the long lines for rotisserie chicken at the front of the Ferry Building Farmer's Market. Come instead for amazing Mexican food served by super friendly people (tucked away at the back of the market). Expect a small, rotating menu of tamales, tortillas, chilaquiles, and more.

The only thing I disagree with other reviewers on is that the chilaquiles are the best thing on the menu; to me, it's the tamales. Easily the best tamales I've had, and worthy of the visit to the Ferry Building on a Saturday.

The chilaquiles are certainly delicious. How could they not be? They're tortilla chips covered in fresh cotija cheese and salsa, with sides of buttery scrambled eggs and super flavorful beans. And maybe they are the best chilaquiles I've had, and it's just that I don't get the fuss over chilaquiles in general.

The tamales are served piping hot, and come with the same deliciously flavorful side of beans (and I'm not usually all that into beans) as well as an equally surprisingly delicious side salad with various kinds of pickled veggies. The corn outside was perfectly steamed and comforting. Yum!

And what's inside the tamales and tacos seems to be on constant rotation, so always something new to try (I had pork tamales, and saw chicken tamales on the menu on another visit -- the same one when I mistakenly opted not to get the tamales).
author: Sravanthi K.

description:
I got hella hyped for this place due to all of the reviews. I think being spoiled by the numerous options of Mexican food in SoCal resulted in my disappointment with Primavera.

Each ingredient in the chilaquiles tasted as it seemed. To sum it up, it was nacho chips with red sauce, sour cream, beans, avocado, and scrambled eggs. 

Having experienced a mind-blowing, what-the-heck-is-in-here chilaquiles from Santa Ana, I walked into the Primavera booth with too high of expectations. Good, but not great!
author: Evelyn N.

description: CHILEQUILLES I cant spell it but I could eat it all day. That sauce you pour on yourself is to die for. Best I've ever had so far
author: Karen T.

description: Yummy tacos! I was waiting for ramen when the lady making the tortillas at Primavera caught my eye. I decided to check out their menu and everything was sold out excect the Lamb Tacos and some Tamales so seeing that it was a popular place, I decided to give the Tacos a try. The Lamb Tacos were delish! I don't even care for lamb on most days but here, it was stewed in some savory, flavorful spices and it was not gamey. The best part were the tortillas which were soft and fluffy. Instead of two thin tortillas, they served the meat on one tortilla and they were chewy and awesome. Even the service was really nice. They were quick and efficient. Everyone I encountered was really friendly, like they cared you took the time to stop by.
author: Jen L.

description: Their chilaquiles put me in my happy place every time. Paired with their exquisite strawberry lemonade, life cannot get much better.
author: LaShonda F.

description:
I'll keep this simple.

If you like to eat... well... things that taste good, track down the Primavera booth at the Saturday Farmer's Market at the Ferry Building.  

I'll let my picture of the chilaquiles dish stand for itself.  Every aspect was tasty, with an interesting mix of textures, flavors, light heat, and just overall yummyness, covered in the creamy trifecta of avocado, sour cream, and queso Cotija.  It was as if the plate was handed to me by Rick Bayless himself.  

Wife loved her a la carte pork tamales so much that she devoured them before I had a chance to snap a pic of them.  It was either get a pic, or get a bite of them myself before they were gone.  Sorry!

10+ minute line to order, plus a 10+ minute wait for your food.  All worth it.  My only regret is that there weren't TWO Saturdays in the 6 days we spent visiting San Francisco, so we could have stopped here again and tried some of the other things on the menu (or the SAME things *sigh*).

4.93 stars.
author: Joe C.

description:
We saw Anthony Bourdain ate here annnnnnnd he made it look so good we HAD to have it!!! 

Line was ridiculously loooooong but let me tell you this. It was worth it! We ordered the famous chilaquiles and the tamale plate. A bit pricy but worth every cent. Meat was tender, the sauce and everything on the plate compliments one another. It's like butter melting in your mouth only BETTER!!!! 

When we come back, we will come back wanting more! I'm already salivating thinking about it now. Some few thousand miles away. Pfff!
author: Isma S.

description: Excellent tasting food from a limited menu that's made quickly. Prices are comparable to other shops at the Ferry Market.
author: Naveen N.

description: It takes a lot to get me to ordering Mexican food early in the morning, but after reading up on the chilaquiles and tamales from Primavera, and with my out-of-town parents in tow, we went for it.  Knowing that the line here gets to be lengthy after they open at 8AM, we got here early to get leg up on the crowd.  We went with the chilaquiles plate and a roasted green chile & cheese tamale.  While the chilaquiles was delicious, especially with those AMAZING chips, the overall favorite was the tamale.  In finishing everything in less than 10 minutes, my dad said that it was one of the best tamales he has had in a really long time.  As an LA native, we know good tamales. As someone who doesn't love Mexican food, I can honestly say that I would go back time and time again to eat from Primavera.  TOTALLY worth the stop if you're at the Ferry Building on Saturday morning!
author: Lisa I.

description:
If you happen to be at the Ferry Farmers Market, do yourself a favor and stop by Primavera - located outside the FM building where the food stands are. They don't serve your typical greasy Mexican grub, but trust me it's just as delicious. We tried the chilaquiles plate and tamale plate which came out to around $15. 

In my opinion, this is the best food stand option at the market, and you can't beat the portion sizes & prices!
author: Juanita D.

description: It's Tuesday and I'm sitting here at work looking up the hashtag #chilaquiles so I can stare at pictures. Does anyone else ever do such a thing? No? Just me? I seriously can't wait for Saturday so I can satisfy my craving!!!! The BEST chilaquiles!
author: Grace V.

description:
I finally got to check out this food stand on a breezy Saturday that was down by the pier!

What caught my eye on their simple menu, was their fish tacos, but I have bookmarked this place ever since way back, to try their Chilaquiles!  

For $9.50, their Chilaquiles was the standard of a fajita plate, but without the meat.  Instead, it was with scrambled eggs and the norm of beans, avocado, cheese, optional side salsa, and chips on the bottom that reminded me of Doritos!  It was more a breakfast meal, to say the least, and it was good, but not the best!

Next time around, I'm getting their tamales and fish tacos!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I'm impressed with Primavera.  I'll admit, I was pretty skeptical about their food because their prices are pretty high compared to other Mexican food joints, but they definitely give you your money's worth in portion size and best of all, their food is really good!! 

My first two visits with them had me try their famous Tamales and Chile Relleno respectively. 

Tamale Plate w/ Butternut Squash & Monterey Cheese and Maurilias Pork. --  http://bit.ly/19SBhnA
Oh man, these tamales!!  So good!  And they frequently change every week so you'll always be bound to try something different.  Both of these were loaded and came with a plate full of extra veggies and beans.  My favorite of the two was definitely the Butternut Squash with Monterey Cheese.  The pic itself doesn't do it justice, but when I cut into the Tamale, I got a nice amount of gooey melted cheese stretching out.  Definitely good stuff and you can't go wrong with ordering this.

Chile Relleno en Nogada --  http://bit.ly/KTKvXy
Beef and pork picadillo relleno with Sourcream walnut sauce and pomegranite
There was a lot going on with this plate.  Very creative with the pomegranite seeds as it added some acidity to the richness of the beef and pork filled Relleno.  This isn't regularly on the menu, but if it does appear again, I wouldn't mind ordering this again too.

So after two visits to Primavera, now I realize what I've been missing out on because I used to always pass by their tent at the Farmers Market but after having their Tamales and Chile Relleno, I can't resist stopping by to take a look at their menu which constantly changes.  Their food is high quality and so far everything I've had has been really good!  I'll definitely be looking forward to see what they have next time and I also have to try their Chilaquiles that everyone seems to be raving about.

I have to thank Anthony Boudain for leading me to yet another awesome eatery.
author: Rodney H.

description:
I LOVE/HATE this place because there are so many other food stands at the Ferry Building Farmers Market on Saturdays and I always am drawn here. 

If you havent tried the amazing chilaquiles, do yourself a huge favor and get some ASAP. Literally started my obsession with chilaquiles after having them here. 

I was also never really a fan of tamales and now have bought the tamales to make at home here several times. The jack and cheese is prob my favorite! I recently hosted a wonderful brunch and had these and they were a hit!
author: Hetal P.

description:
I hate to ruin the party, but I just don't get the hype. I stopped by on a Saturday morning during the farmer's market for their "famous" chilaquiles. For ten dollars, I was expecting something super delicious and unique.

Service was prompt and friendly, and the dish was visually appealing. However, everything seemed to taste one dimensional-- the eggs were cooked nicely and the chile sauce was tasty-- but the combination of all of the items tasted plain. I found the fried tortillas to be oily and not as tasty as regular tortillas??!

Anyways, I might swing by again to sample the fish tacos. Overall, I don't fully understand the hype.
author: Jackson L.

description:
I consider myself an expert on chilaquiles, I eat them about every other week from many different places, including home made ones :) 
That being said, these chilaquiles are simple, with absolutely nothing wrong with them. They are full of good flavor and have a good mix of ingredients without being overwhelming. I don't give them 5 starts only because I would like them to have an option for meat. The place itself has food you don't find just anywhere or is not the usual "Mexican-american made" like in most taquerias or fast food Mexican places. The juices are healthy and go perfectly with the meals.
author: Sergio L.

description:
Only had time to try one item, but I had seen the chilaquiles listed as a must order here.

It's a breakfast item and often cited as a hangover food.  Made with tortillas, refried beans, scrambled eggs, sour cream, salsa and avocado, the dish is kinda what one might conjur up in the morning from your own kitchen.

It was tasty, but I didn't find it particularly noteworthy, although the scrambled eggs were nicely done.  

I hear the tamales and tacos are great here too, so maybe I need to try those.
author: Randy F.

description: Poor service and over priced food.  I don't mind paying for good food but I sure didn't get bang for the buck, nor was it even good.
author: Lehrie H.

description:
So good! We had the chilaquiles and fish tacos. So good! It's a bit pricy at around $10 per serving, but it's definitely top quality. Everything is super fresh. We saw them making their tortillas on the spot (not just heating them up, but actually press them from a dough and making them), and cutting avocados to make guacamole. 

I love how they only have 4-5 things on the menu but everything is super tasty. They really have perfected their food. I would say this is the best Mexican breakfast in SF. 

The line is long but it moves fast, but after you order, they make your food so that's quite a bit of wait. Totally worth it, though.
author: Wendy K.

description: Primavera is the first place I go at the Ferry Plaza Farmers Market. Primavera is often the best food I eat all week. Yes, of course the chilaquiles is the best ever, but I LOVE their carne asada with pineapple tacos, the ceviche is incredible (when they have it), and basically anything with masa is perfection. They always have the chilaquiles and tamales, plus two other dishes that rotate week to week. I've often found that the weirder the description of the dish, the better it is. Go often and try all of their offerings because you won't be disappointed. I never think about how much money I'm spending there (and it's about $10/plate) because the food is so good! It's rare for me, as a value-conscious person, feels that way.
author: Victoria J.

description:
Always a favorite stop at the Ferry Building Farmer's market. A couple months back, got to try a couple new things and wasn't disappointed!

* Niman ranch beef tacos de birria "tatemada" salsa de arbol, onions cilantro - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/primavera-san-francisco?select=3ttf7BYtFve9Avg34RdetA#LO_f-5_uSkR_CMYBNLgVAA
Great flavor to the meat, and love the simple fresh toppings. You can add your own salsas too. 

* Tamales - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/primavera-san-francisco?select=3ttf7BYtFve9Avg34RdetA#3ttf7BYtFve9Avg34RdetA
Tried a bite of my friend's - soft and moist, tasty!

* Hibiscus Juice - 4 stars
Tart, fresh, unique!
author: Ziyan C.

description:
We were browsing all the stalls at the Saturday Farmers market trying to decide what to eat when we stumbled upon Primavera. 

My friend decided she had to try their birra tacos (3 per order $9.50) for two reasons. One, they make their tortillas by hand to order and two she wanted to compare it to her dad's birra. 

She enjoyed the tortilla and thought it was better than how her grandma/mom makes them. However, her dad's birra was way better than Primavera's version. For me, I agreed with the tortilla but since I can't recall if I have had birra before I thought it was fine. I did think the meat was a little "mushy" but I think its how it should be?

Next time her dad makes birra I'm invited!

Overall Thoughts

I'll have to come back again and try something else but for now Primavera is A-OK
author: Eddie W.

description:
Favorite Saturday morning activity in SF: eating chilaqueles with extra tasty primavera salsa at the ferry building farmers market.

Do yourself a favor and buy some salsa to take home.
author: Stine H.

description:
If you see a line for food...Stand in it. My other thought is, follow your nose.  I was drawn to this stand a few years ago by the yummy scent of chilies.  But the Chilaquiles hang in my mind, they are  the benchmark against which I measure all other chilaquiles.

The chips may be fresh and deep fried.  They are puffy.  The chipotle sauce is  fantastic.  Eggs scrambled soft fantastic, refried beans OK, avocado...I'm always up for that. Crumbled cheese a nice topping.

I hate to admit it, but I love these so much I haven't tried anything else from this booth.  At $9.00 a plate they are a bit pricey but one can be split between two people.
author: Sam V.

description: Favorite food stand at the Ferry Building Farmer's Market on Saturdays. Get the chilaquiles. They are the only thing I ever get but I hear the tamals are also great. Fresh, fast, colorful food with lovely service.
author: Semuteh F.

description: Agree with the majority here.  Tasty chilaquiles!  All the ingredients on the plate from the eggs to the beans, sauce, avocados etc made for a tasty combination.  The chips were solid and held up well to the sauce.  We had a late breakfast here and the line moved fairly quickly.  This was a filling meal and I would not hesitate to come back for more if I lived in SF.
author: louli e.

description: Best Chilaquiles ever! Especially with their salsa. Also grab a cup of pineapple and cucumber juice there - perfect to go with the spicy food and to start a lovely Saturday at Fert building.
author: Kai-wing B.

description:
One of the highlights of going to the Ferry Bldg. Farmer's Market is getting to try different food spots.  

Today hubby and  I decided to try this spot.  Friends have told me they have good chilaquiles and yup they were right.  

We ordered the Chilaquiles Verde and fish tacos! Truly yum! Yea it's a bit expensive compared to regular spots but they give you a lot and ingredients are fresh.  Even my husband who's not a fan of chilaquiles actually liked it.  Ahh I wanna go back!
author: Claire J.

description:
Who has the longest line of the cooking stands at the Ferry Building's Saturday market?  Look no further. In reviewing the menu, the enchilada and tamales sounded like my likely choices, but, in watching the food being picked up, the Chilaqiles El Cardinal ($9.50) became my choice.  Comprised of their freshly made crispy tortilla topped with tomato chipotle sauce, soft cooked eggs (covered with hot sauce), fresh avocado slices, and refried beans, this plate made for a hearty breakfast(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/6nPRtXL7lSg48stPsMLU4g?select=bAHDSbpJE3kKJkW9OBgOyw).  It was so good that I needed to pause after my first bite.  It was amazing to taste so many flavors and textures on that one plate.  A definite welcome surprise from my two previous Mexican food experiences.
No doubt why they have the longest lines!
author: Mike C.

description: NEVER DISAPPOINTS!!!! I look forward to Saturday mornings just so I can get my Primavera fix. I've never had a better fish taco. They are so incredible I come here to eat them for breakfast! Their salsa: awesome. Chips: no comparison. They are a staple at our place and so much cheaper to buy from them directly than going to Whole Foods. Highly recommend the fish tacos, or if they have then the crispy chicken tacos or chicken chalupa! (I don't eat beef so can't comment on those dishes, but I'm sure they're fantastic, too!).
author: Marissa B.

description:
Apparently Chilaquiles in mexico is consider as hangover food. Who cares if it is or isn't this is definitely the best place to get it. It is probably a really inconvenient place to get it if you do have a hang over, but I go there every chance i get.

The menu is pretty simple - Chilaquiles or tacos. Get the chilaquiles!

The tortillas are made fresh then fried than topped with amazing marinara sauce served with a side of organic eggs, refried beans and avocado. The tortillas are soft from the sauce but still has a small bite to it - the perfect texture. The eggs taste really fresh and has that organic taste to it. The plate is well put together - perfect value for $10

PS. You can buy the marinara sauce and tortillas at whole foods. It almost taste exactly the same!
author: Ryan R.

description:
It was cold, windy, and rainy. But I was hungry and determined to find some breakfast at the Farmer's Market. I had visited many times before, but never stopped here for their chilaquiles or tamales. Well, this was it. I was teetering back and forth on what to order, but everyone else in front on me ordered the chilaquiles.

*Thumbs up*
There's nothing original or creative about the chilaquiles dish -- it's just a combo plate of scrambled eggs, refried beans, and a bunch of tortilla chips covered in sauce, cotija cheese, and avocado. But put everything together, it was just so fresh, filling, and comforting.

*Thumbs down*
That I didn't have enough stomach space to try one of their tamales. Next time.
author: Dru C.

description:
Open Saturday's only from 8 am to 2 pm, Primavera is a simple stand in the open-air Farmers Market behind the Ferry Building at Embarcadero. And yet, this small stand offers up deliciously fresh Mexican food worth writing about. 

I arrived at the Ferry Building just before 8 am and was one of two people in line. I ordered the Tamale Plate ($9.50) consisting of two pork tamales, refried black beans and pickled vegetables. Service at this early hour took no more than two minutes. A small vat of red salsa sits atop the order pick-up table.

How was it? The entire dish was fantastic. Everything goes well together. However, the salsa was very mild so I hope they entertain the idea of having mild and hot salsas in the future. 

Tips/Thoughts:

-There is limited table seating in this area of the Ferry Building. You're better off finding a bench, enjoying the view of the Bay Bridge in the near proximity. 
-Cash Only.
-My understanding is the menu changes some every so often, but they always have the Chilaquiles and Tamales on there.
author: Tom R.

description:
So delicious!! I don't know what was better, the atmosphere during the farmers market or the food itself. Either way, it was all amazing. I got the first option, don't remember what it was and it was so delicious. So many flavors! I initially forgot to get the sauce that was on the side but after a few bites I went back and poured it on and did it make a difference!!

I wanted to get a drink but I forgot to while I was ordering and the line was way too long to go back. But they looked delicious and people seemed to enjoy them so I recommend checking them out. 

The price was also excellent. Big portions as well. 

I want to go back to San Francisco just to eat here. Sigh, if only.
author: Sepi E.

description:
Their chilaquiles is one of the best prepared food options you can get at Ferry Building.  It's not a chilaquiles you would expect to find in the Mission, but it's fantastic in its own right.  It's lighter, fresher, and has its own farmers market spin on it: scrambled eggs, refried beans, fresh slices of avocado, sour cream and, queso fresco.  It's well worth the mess you'll make eating it!

The only downside is that the line is consistently long and it can be a little bit of a wait for your food, but what isn't at the Ferry Building farmer's market?
author: Carrie C.

description: Delicious! Delicious! Delicious! I l've driven from San Jose and Santa Cruz many a times to eat here on Saturday mornings. The chillaquilles are the best I've ever had but a little spicy. They have come with a red or a green salsa.. I think depending on the season but both are great. The beans are so flavorful and the eggs are cooked just right. Tips: parking sucks! Try and find parking on the street and walk. The farmers market can be crowded, and the line for Primavera long- but they work quickly so be patient! Bring something to drink! The plate can sometimes be on the spicier side and although they have drinks to choose from, I always enjoy some ice cold water. Get here before they close, because they do run out of certain dishes earlier in the day. Wish they were closer to me! ALSO .. Try their roasted chipotle salsa sold at Whole Foods markets in Nor Cal. So good! Bon appetite!
author: Kelly P.

description: I dream about one day finding some chilaquilles as good as these closer to home. How do you make them so crispy? The sauce is the perfect spicy, the egg are cooked just right. This is my favorite thing when I visit San Francisco, and I have been know to schedule flights to be in town for the farmers market.  I am always tempted by some of the other food stands but this is by far the best and others must agree from the ever growing line.
author: Kim L.

description:
FML! CHILAQUILES!

Why are they so delicious?! It's almost impossible to be so good.. or is it? Screw the Roli Roti lines... come here for a better piece of heaven on your Saturday morning.
author: Joanne Y.

description:
I wouldn't think the Farmer's Market would have awesome Mexican but it definitely does. I'm generally not a big fan of chilaquiles but Primavera's served up a great breakfast on a Saturday morning. A picture is worth a thousand words. 

See: http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2711/4414326208_8aff32321d_b.jpg

I will DEFINITELY be going back for more. It is worth 5 stars but at $10 it is a bit pricy.
author: Carlos A.

description:
I came to Privevera with the expectations of the best chilaquiles ever. I was pleasantly surprised to find that the day I went they were serving chilaquiles verde (my preference) rather than rojo (their usual). 

Let me be real and say that I wasn't amazed. The sauce was ok. The main positive was that the chips were PERFECT chilaquiles chips. They were crunchy enough to hold up to being drowned in sauce. The huge chunks of avocado was a nice addition. The eggs really kind of got me down though. I'm not an expert in the chilaquiles field, but my local spot serves their eggs over easy and there is something magnificent to breaking the yolk on the chips. The taste is outstanding. And this is now my preference. The scrambled eggs Primavera dished up were disappointing. At $10 per plate...it didn't feel like the right investment of my dollars or my stomach.

My sister, however, came raving about the fish tacos. She insisted I snag a bite of one of hers and they did NOT disappoint! YUMMY! I honestly wanted to steal more but thought it was the right thing to do to eat my chilaquiles. 

I enjoyed the scenery at the Saturday Ferry Plaza Farmer's Market and eating my breakfast by the water (and next to a bum). 

I would love to come back and try the red chilaquilas and other menu offerings (and get one of those fish tacos to myself). I will update after my next trip to SF!
author: Leah H.

description: I like this palace!  My favorite breakfast with nachos! Simple ingredients but an absolutely amazing combination! The price are excellent !!
author: Pilow K.

description:
The food is pretty good at this food stand, in the Ferry building's Saturday farmers market. It's also one of the most popular food vendors. But at $9.50 per plate, the prices are more than double what you'll pay at most Mexican taquerias. Frozen tamales and containers of salsas (one of my favorite salsas) are also available for sale to take home.

Pork tacos and tamales:
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/ZTxZdWZjD37RtRSkDML1Kg/l
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/hi3wjj41YYu7-QkdaNF-Cg/l

Food quality and taste is 4-5 stars + price is 2 stars = 3 stars.
author: Luis C.

description:
It took Anthony Bourdain's cynically sinister stroll through the Ferry Building Farmers' Market on his addictive show, "No Reservations", to tempt me to come here against my bitter...uhhh, I mean my better judgment. That and the fact that rising star chef David Chang was signing his new Momofuku cookbook at Sur Le Table later that morning. He's the one that recently said that "...every restaurant in San Francisco is serving figs on a plate with ...nothing on it". (BTW, he's also the one with me in my current profile picture...his food is amazing regardless of his smarmy comment!) 

Anyway, I never felt motivated to walk beyond the Rose Pistola kiosk to navigate the swarming crowds at the market until I saw the tamale plate Bourdain had on the show. Since Jamie W. and I had an hour before the book signing, we waited in line at the Primavera stand for one of their fabled Mexican breakfasts. There were four desirable selections on the framed menu, and I went with the $9.50 Chilaquiles "El Cardenal", which was a paper plate of chilaquiles with tomato and chipotle in adobe sauce accompanied by scrambled eggs, onions, crema, and refried beans (see photo). 

It was a tad pricey for what you get, but the combination of flavors burst in my mouth with every bite, especially the spicy kick of the chipotle. You certainly can't beat the view of the Bay Bridge, and there was never a shortage of weather-worn wooden benches to sit on to be able to lap it all up. I'll definitely come back for the tamales and the enchiladas on some other Saturday, and perhaps I can also be cool and cynical like those bad-boy chefs. 

FOOD - 4 stars...a solid four-star plate of food with Ferry Building prices 
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...the Bay Bridge on a sunny day 
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...efficient for sure 
TOTAL - 4 stars...Bourdain is right again, dammit
author: Ed U.

description:
Oh my god. SO good. I am so sad it took me 2 years of living in San Francisco to discover this!

* Field of Greens - 5 stars!!
(with scrambled eggs, refried beans, sour cream, avocado, queso cotija, white onion and cilantro)

The scrambled eggs were DELICIOUS. So soft & fluffy, creamy, flavorful, I wonder how they made them so good! The beans were really good (I got black beans, not pinto beans)...though still second to the amazing black beans at Gracias Madre.... Sour cream seemed homemade--fresh, light, and tasty. Cotija cheese is my weakness and it was a really great addition.

I ordered with a friend and split it and still, it was so much food! So while it's sort of expensive to get a full plate for $10, I think it's a lot of food.

I guess the one thing I would have wished is that they had given me some of their really awesome-looking guacamole instead of just cut up avocados...

**Note to vegetarians--As I ordered, I asked if the refried beans were totally vegetarian and my server was very nice and told me that while they weren't the black beans were. So be sure to ask for the beans that are vegetarian!
author: Neeharika B.

description: Met some new friends at the Embarcadero farmers market. Got my blue bottle coffee and off we went to explore. We made a beeline to Primavera for the breakfast tortilla meal. WOW was this delicious. I had to order additional stuff just to taste everything. Pork Tamale  best tamale I've ever had, moist overflowing with pork. Chalupa with Chicken again everything made fresh on site as you watch amazing! The line and wait were long as you would expect when you have a winner.
author: Rick F.

description:
We stopped her on the way to the spa for brunch.  Their chilaquiles was delicious!  The chips were somehow still very crispy and it tasted great.  The fish tacos were pretty good, and their salsa was very yummy.

I'd prefer Hapa Ramen to this if they were there, but overall not a bad stop at the farmer's market to take.
author: Tracy L.

description: One of the best chilaquiles ($10) around anywhere. Also has some dope beer battered fish tacos ($10 for two). They usually have these two plates and a couple others every Saturday. Also offers some refreshing drinks - hibiscus tea and another fruity (orange lime) one, ranging from $3.75 to $5. In my humble opinion, this is one of the top 3 food stands at the Ferry Bldg - along w/ 4505 Meats and Roli Roti.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Ordered food for 8 people, and they mixed up 1 item and failed to even add another item from the order.

Complained and got one item replaced by the server, but the manager refused to fix the second item and got very defensive and brought out a separate receipt for it.

The food tastes fine, but so does the food from any Taqueria in the Mission. When you charge 3x as much as this stuff costs to make you would think they could eat $6 for screwing up a $100 order.
author: Mark F.

description: The chilaquilles are unbelievable. I have been hearing about this place for some time so when I was in town I had to make the trip - so worth it.
author: Cris V.

description:
This tiny little stand, hidden in a sea of people, with a line stretching all the way to the water, smelling like hot peppers and searing meat and fresh squeezed lemons, serenaded exclusively by a man with a sweet alto voice... I have Yelp to thank for even beginning to be able to find it.  And for enlightening me to the existence of the Embarcadero farmers' market in the first place.  I am a thankful tourist - thankful that I didn't end up at Fisherman's Wharf being sorry I ate at one of the crappy seafood restaurants, toured Alcatraz for $25, and/or stuffed my face with Ghirardelli chocolate whilst touring Ripley's Believe-it-or-not museum.

Anyway, what I'm trying to say is that my experience at Primavera was the opposite of those things.  I had the tamale plate - one of each of the pork green chile and the beef with tomato salsa, plus black beans.  My boyfriend ordered something which I have forgotten the name of, but it was like two crispy giant tortilla chips stuffed with ricotta cheese and some other stuff... but mostly ricotta cheese.

5 stars for my tamales.  3 for his tortilla thingy.  While both of them were mouth-meltingly good on the first few bites, my meal stood up to the test of time, and the test of 'oh my god I'm so full is it worth the stomachache to finish this?'.  Those tamales were complex and spicy and full of surprises at every bite.  The black beans - and I'm not even generally too crazy about black beans - were the best black beans I'd ever had.  I licked the plate clean of them.

My boyfriend's dish, however, just got very ricotta-cheesey the more of it I ate, and it definitely needed salsa to spice it up.

But our drinks!  Strawberry lemonade and pineapple-cucumber limeade, both ladled out of giant jars and clearly homemade.  The lemonade had nice crunchy seeds at the bottom that I gobbled up when I finished the drink.  In a uniquely Californian way, everything tasted like you were sipping the juice directly out of a fruit still swinging from the tree.

And to the man who serenaded the group of kids by our table with an extended version of 'Old MacDonald Had A Farm', complete with realistic animal noises - thank you.  This was the perfect soundtrack to our meal.
author: Hannah E.

description:
Best Chilaquiles  Ever. No question about it.

if you don't know what chilaquiles are, here's a quick rundown of what to expect from Primavera's Chilaquiles:

Corn tortilla chips, smothered in a red (usually) salsa, topped with sour cream, avocado, onions and cilantro. Served with scrambled eggs and a side of beans (usually re-fried i believe).

that's it, simple enough. Admittedly it sounds a little pricey when you consider the simplicity of the ingredients list, but the final product is much greater than the sum of all it's parts. It's totally worth it, and it's totally worth the wait in line as well.

The agua frescas are usually really good also, so definitely give those a shot.

I've brought many many people to try these chilaquiles for their first time ever, and literally it never fails. Every single one of them totally loved it.

Just to clear up some potential confusion, Primavera is not a restaurant inside the Ferry building. It is a food stand that is open for business during the Saturday Farmers Market at the Ferry building. Go to the back of the building and walk towards the restaurant behind the Ferry Building. look for the white tent with the long line.
author: Charles Michael B.

description: Sometimes, the best advertising is other people buying food. The chilaquiles are otherworldly, as good as they look. And the seafood (shrimp, scallop, octopus) tostadas are unbelievable and giant. Both come with hella avocado. So legit, probably the best meal at the Farmer's Market.
author: Maximillian M.

description: I've changed flights so I could get to Primavera for chilaquiles on Saturday morning.
author: Bradley H.

description: If you're looking for a pretty amazing breakfast at the Farmer's Market and don't want anything super fancy inside, Primavera is the place for you.  The Chilaquiles Aquascalientes is SO good no wonder there was a line right when it opened in the morning.  Check it out!
author: Blake B.

description: The chilaquiles are a great vegetarian option at the farmers market. But maybe I'm just a sucker for avocado.
author: Kelly R.

description:
On my 4th visit I really had to write a review: the best Chilaquilles ever!!!!

Food in San Francisco is amazing...so amazing that even food stands can be incredible.  This spot in the Ferry Building is no exception - great quality food.  While it is a little on the pricey side for what would normally cost about $4 at a taqueria, this is great quality stuff.  I almost always get the Chilaquilles - tortilla chips topped with a spicy red chile enchilada sauce; this is served with fresh refried beans, amazing and rich scrambled eggs 9the best scrambled eggs I've ever had!) and sour cream and avocados.  

At $10, it's a bit much for breakfast without waiter service, but this is San Francisco and with the food that good, it's totally worth it.
author: Ken G.

description:
I had the ceviche tostadas here. They are truly incredible, and doubly so considering they are served from a tent at the farmers market. The fish was very fresh, well cured, and incredibly flavorful without being overly fishy. 

Do it!
author: Nathan S.

description:
After stuffing myself with pluots and dark chocolate almond bark outside the ferry building, I saw people with these amazing-looking plates of food containing avocado, beans, and just overall goodness.  I asked someone where he got his food, and he told me Primavera was the supplier of his plate of happiness. 

I quickly searched the place on Yelp to determine what to order, and I settled on the chilaquiles. The ingredients were so incredibly simple - tortilla chips covered in some tomato-based sauce (yet still crunchy), refried beans, avocado, scrambled eggs, sour cream, onion, and cheese. The sum truly is larger than its parts, because together it was delicious. I recommend loading up all the ingredients - yes, the eggs too - on a chip. Heavenly! 

Overall, it wasn't mind-blowing amazing, but it's definitely worth a lunch trip to the Ferry Building. It is rather expensive/over-priced though (for one plate of chilaquiles and two strawberry frescas, $17?!?!?! Ain't no brokeass Berkeley student got time for that). But I'm definitely willing to go back to try their chalupas and other mouth-watering menu items!
author: Crystal J.

description:
OUT OF CONTROL ...AMAZING!

Seriously, every time I come up north to visit my boyfriend we make it a point to take a trip to the Ferry Bldg on Saturday just to get some of this delicious food. The chilaquiles are out of this world ...
My mouth is water as I type this review.
yes, they are THAT good!

I've also tried their fish tacos, can't go wrong with these either. So tasty, and perfectly made. They really know what they're doing here.

If you ever have a chance to get their chalupa, DO IT.
I'm pretty convinced that there is no way you can go wrong with anything on their menu!

It's wonderful to enjoy such amazing food, consistently. The quality is always great, fresh and full of flavor. The fact that they are mobile at farmers markets is very impressive - I don't think I could say enough wonderful things about this food!
author: Nikki R.

description:
It's tough for me to try other vendors at the Ferry Building farmer's market on Saturdays when Primevera beckons. I usually get the tamales plate and put a few spoonfuls of their salsa on top. It's heaven on a plate. They offer a meat option and a veggie option and change it up depending on the day. One of my favorites forgotten treasures is the pickled veggies that they put on the side. So yummy and lessens the guilt of stuffing myself full of carbs.

I tried their chilaquiles and didn't like it all that much. I have friends that swear by it though. I thought it was a bit over salted and the eggs were over cooked. The chips had that not soggy but not crunchy texture that I didn't like. I wish they would just use un-fried tortillas. I'll give it another try though. Maybe I just had it on a bad day.

The boy had their fish tacos and loved it too. I had a few bites and thought the flavor combination was on the mark. The fish was so tender and melts in your mouth. Although I thought that with such a good piece of seafood, why fry it? The ginger peach tea was amazing too. 

Another San Francisco go-to spot for me.
author: Alice W.

description: There's only 3 things on this overpriced menu so every one of them better be the best thing ever. After spending $13.50 for a plate of chilaquiles and a jamaica tea, I'd say the food was above average, but not worth the price. The chilaquiles came in a roja sauce that was tasty enough, but nothing special. There was a side of scrambled eggs and overly salty beans. The plate was enough for me, but I have a small appetite so I can see a regular guy being hungry after.
author: Judy C.

description:
Yelp was a complete let down on this one.
We had the much advertised Chilaquiles, and an order of the beer battered fish Tacos for lunch today, and the food was a big disappointment. 

Primarily, the flavors were completely lacking, and the food was pretty greasy. People serving the food seemed to be doing so with bare hands - no gloves! What's up with that??

The best Mexican food that I have had yet has been from Santa Fe, New Mexico, and this place just doesn't cut it for me. Won't be back.
author: Snowy W.

description: I'm a huge fan of the ferry building farmers market, but I typically always get the same things.  I managed to pull myself away this time to try something new.  Seeing all the plates of chilaquiles and chalupas this place seemed like a solid place to try.  I got the pastor tacos and the chicken chalupa.  Great, fresh ingredients.  A bit difficult to eat either one with a fork though, but when you hold them it gets all over the place.  oyyyy oh well, it's still delicious.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Sometimes the long booth lines can be deceiving because you assume that the food has something worth drawing people in.  But in the end, it could just be a monkey see, monkey do kinda thing.  That's how it was with Roli Roti Gourmet Rotisserie and this place too (but not as bad).

The man and I ended up getting a Chicken Chalupa plate ($9) & a single Pork Tamale ($4.25--comes with a side of black beans). There was one other dish on the menu which was sold out.  I think it was a breakfast plate of some sort and I hope that wasn't the main attraction.

 The chicken chalupa is topped with sour cream, guacamole, and salsa.  I wish the masa dough was cooked crisper--it was sort of in between.  The pork tamale is well... a pork tamale.  I think I had a more flavorful one at the dainty Castro Valley farmer's market (and that was without sauce).  Now don't get me wrong, it really does not get any fresher than this.  You can tell that the tamales were only made yesterday and the chalupas are cooked right in front of you.  BUT everything tasted rather bland.  Even though the pork tamale was layered with what seemed like enchilada sauce; it didn't really help.

What's cool is that they offer all these exotic drinks: ginger-peach iced tea, hibiscus Jamaican juice, and some blackberry drink.  I saw tons of people drinking it but thought I'd pass.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Outstanding chilaquiles! Everything done to perfection, and a generous serving of avocado on top. 
A Saturday morning, a plate of chilaquiles, sitting on a bench watching the bustle of the ferry market, with the water behind you - a marvelous San Fran experience.
author: J B.

description: They are friendly people who make great food. Simple and fresh ingredients cooked well and compliments each other. I had the chilaquiles and it was great and very filling.
author: Jason Z.

description:
This was so much better than it looked like it might be.

Great tamale. Great black beans. Garnishes all so fresh and crispy and crunchy. Delicious house made pickles (cauliflower, carrot, etc.).

Pork sopes were unreal delicious. Just wow.
author: Eric B.

description:
Mom ordered the Chili Colorado chilaquiles when we were here two months ago.  Those things were awesome.  She loved them, and she is hard to please when it comes to Mexican food.  They were tasty and were full of flavor.  My mom judges breakfast restaurants by their chilaquiles, and these were top notch.  Better than almost all of the ones have had in Mexico.  I was surprised to find such good food here. Oh, they come with beans.  Eat them up.  

Only drawback?  Almost $10 a plate.  Damn Gina, they are just fried tortillas!  Still, when I come back to eat at the Farmer's Market, Primavera will be the place to be for me.
author: Humberto G.

description:
The things I will do to avoid writing a final presentation on a gorgeous Saturday in SF...
1. So You Think You Can Dance Hulu marathon in bed.
2. Put on make up to go outside for 30 minutes.
3. Stand in the lunchtime line for Primavera's tamales.
4. Write Yelp reviews.

I love tamales. Don't really know why... they are homely little things. Have you seen a tamale photograph well?? Nope. Although when I think of it in terms of mashed carbs with saucy savory goodness in the center, it makes a little more sense. 

Ordered a plate of two tamales, one maurilias pork and one white corn squash n cheese, served with black beans and pickled veggies; and a hibiscus juice:

Pros
My drink was free. I don't know if that's normal.
The beans were bangin. mm creamy, smoky, and topped with queso fresco.
Service is pretty quick and friendly.
The tamales are big. 

Cons:
Along with being big (good), the tamales were way too dense (boo). I've been ruined by Rick Bayless' creamy, light, fluffy sweet corn tamales at Frontera Fresco and the masa here pales in comparison. The filling was also pretty tasteless and underwhelming.
Hibiscus juice a little too tart, though at least it wasn't cloyingly sweet.

I've lost my train of thought. I'm in tamale depression. The chilaquiles were ogle-worthy though so maybe I will give those a try next time.

***UPDATE***
Ok. I'm adding a star to bring my review to 4. I just vacuumed up an entire plate of chilaquiles, topped off by a satisfying buddha-belly pat. The salsa-drenched tortillas were the perfect level of crisp, and balanced out the soft textures of the eggs, avocado, really fresh sour cream, and refried beans. Other reviews are right, the eggs aren't anything special; I also prefer the black beans that come with the tamale dish to these refried beans. But the whole plate comes together really really nicely, and I'm glad I was constrained to whatever was on my plate because I would not be able to stop if an entire platter was in front of me.
Also, drinks do not come with the meal. I must have just lucked out last time!
author: Michelle Y.

description:
This place kicks Mama's(the Restaurant! not real mama:-) ass as far as breakfast goes.  IMHO their breakfast is just DELICIOUS.  Their 3 citrus fresca is the most delectable drink I have ever had.  It had just enough sourness to counter the sweetness, first time I have ever finished my juice, it was that Good! Their Chilaquiles with Chorizo is awesome, the scrambled eggs goes perfectly with the Chorizo.  The chips was also great with some sort of covering on them.  Since the guy sitting next to me had some tamale I had to tried them.  I ordered the pork and chicken tamale.  I felt the pork tamale was better than the chicken tamale which was slightly dry.  Overall, perfect Mexican breakfast for the champions! :-)

Update:

1/26/08

I am always surprised at how restaurants owners think?
I mean if there are things that people like, do you take it away just to be funny?

I went to the farmer's market today for my breakfast. 

Me: I would like a Chilaquiles with Chorizo please?
WASPY guy: We do not have that today?
Me: What do you mean? I had it last week?
WASPY guy: well, last week we had another dish with the Chorizo so we have Chorizo with potatoes but today we don't.
Me: OK, I will have the Chilaquiles with the 3 citrus drink.

Now I know why this place is still in the ferry building farmer's market.  I mean the thing about restaurants is their consistency.  Every time you order a Big Mac you know what it will taste like.  OK, it ain't great but at least you know what you are going to get.  I mean do they say sorry we do not have Egg Mac-muffin today because we do not have Bacon today? No. They don't!

BTW, the Chilaquiles was completely different than the one I had last week.  The scramble eggs was stone cold, and even the 3 citrus drink tasted exactly like lemonade.  WTF.  That was it.
author: Jim J.

description: Hands down- best chilaquiles I've ever had eaten.  They use the best quality ingredients.  They make the chips, which are great without any salsa, in case you want to buy them separately.  The eggs are humanely raised and local.  These eggs sell for about $10 a dozen at the grocery store.  So $9.50 for a meal here is a deal considering the quality and ethics!
author: Burger T.

description:
This food stand rocks! I'm not a huge fan of Mexican food coz it's like the same ingredient that's Been assembled in many ways but this one is different. One of the best Mexican food ever! And the corn tortilla omg! 
I was hoping to try their ceviche earlier but they don't have it today. I didn't know they change the menu often. However, I am so happy with my order. I got chile rellenos and it is so damn delicious. I've had this dish before but this one is absolutely better! Way better! As in 100 miles way better! :D the sauce on top is good with pomegrante bits. Weird but good.

They also have fresh squeezed juices. The one i got is pomelo. Good! ;) but I don't think it's for everyone.  

I'm hooked now in this food stand.
author: Cryszilla G.

description:
I wanted to love this place so much. I missed it last saturday and spent all week waiting until this saturday, planning my meal based off of reviews here. I'm a vegetarian, and a brunch lover and mexican food aficianado, so I was really emotionally invested in this experience. It was hard to find as it was lunch time and it was all the way in the back of the farmers market near the water. There were masses of people there and no way of discerning where the ordering line ended and the pick up line began. I just looked at the menu and  jumped in near the register. I couldn't decide between the chilequile and the tamale dish so I got one tamale ala cart. The chilequile dish was $9.50 and the tamale was $5 and I couldn't decide between the pineapple cucumber or strawberry limonade juice so I got them both for $7.50. I was so excited, and the long queue of people was validation so I couldn't imagine the impending let down after a week of build up.

The only thing on my order of any worth was the pineapple cucumber which earned this review one star, the other star was for using organic ingredients. It was sweet but not overly so and refreshing, perfect for the warm sunny weather. The strawberry limonade was very tart at the top and got sweeter towards the bottom, it was weird.  I was looking forward to this chilequile dish so I took one of the soggy but firm tortilla chip and I was already hating the texture and dipped it into the black beans (their refried pinto beans are NOT vegetarian) and was taken aback by the saltiness. I thought wow i'm going to be bloated from the fluid retention and sent into a hypertensive state. I was hoping it would get better but the second bite was less satisfying than the first. Then it hit me... It tastes exactly like soggy CHEESY DORRITOS with beans and eggs... gross. I couldn't believe I spent over $20 bucks for this. I took off a star for the saltiness of this food.

 I took off another when I went to taste the potato and swiss chard tamale and saw meat in it, they messsed up my order. They were apologetic but Instead of giving me a new tamale and they threw the entire plate away. I admonished the guy on being wasteful. They gave me a new plate right away. I should have opted then for the greasy chile relleno so that I could have tasted all of their lackluster offerings. I couldn't finish the chilequile plate, the swiss chard tamale wasn't any better, it lacked depth of flavor, had very little chard in it, it tasted like a mexican take on a  samosa but without the spices and crunchy textures of an indian one. The person next to me also had a plate full of that wet dorrito flavored tortilla chips that went uneaten. Don't waste your time here. If you still decide to go, think of soggy cheesy dorritos when you bite down and think of me saying I told ya so. BTW search for dorritos in other reviews. I'm not the only person who thought it tastes like processed junk food.
author: Onika C.

description:
4 stars for the seafood ceviche. While I was waiting and wasting my time at Namu, my mother was waiting for the seafood ceviche at Primavera. The ceviche was prepared very well. I could taste the freshly squeezed lime/lemon mixture over the sweet delicate shrimp. Mixed with a lovely pico di gallo and topped with fresh ripe avocado and served on a freshly fried tortilla, easily made my morning. 

Primavera also had a sampling of their fresh tortilla chips and a bean dipping sauce that was very delicious. Will def. come back and try the other Mexican delights when I'm back in the bay. Totally worth waking up at 630a to beat the crowd at the Ferry Building Farmers Market.
author: Marcus L.

description:
** I suggest getting a half-order of chilaquiles verdes, since it is a ginormous portion.  A lot of people were getting a half-order of that, and also a half-order of the the tostada ceviche.

It's OK, but not worth a trip.  Here is what I had (see my photos):

Chilaquiles verdes: green chilaquiles with a sauce of chile poblano-tomatillo sour cream, avocado, onion-cilantro cotija cheese, Free range local eggs and refried beans: $9.50.  It was OK.

shrimp and snapper tostadas de ceviche: with avocdo, lime mayonnaise and tapatio salsa: $10.  It was OK.

Also on the menu was:
- beef brisket crispy tacos $9.50
- mole amarillo chicken tamales $9.50
- mushroom spinach tamales with chipotle salsa $9.50
- aguas frescas: jamaica-lime, pineapple cucumber, watermelon/mint lime.
author: Scott F.

description:
I'm going to make Primavera's chilaquiles a "must have" every time I'm in town on a Saturday morning. Navigating through the crowds and busy farmer's market was a bit hectic, but trust me, it was well worth the trek. The chilaquiles were the perfect crispiness, and were complimented well by the sour cream, onion, and fresh avocado toppings. Plus, I was pleasantly surprised at how good the eggs (buttery!) and beans (topped with cotija cheese!) sides were. Eating this delicious plate with a gorgeous view of the bay and Bay Bridge was picture perfect. Wish I lived in SF just so I could spend every Saturday like that.

PS-I'm from San Diego (where mexican food is at its best) and have had chilaquiles in TJ, and I would still say Primavera's chilaquiles is one of the best I've had.
author: Cha V.

description: Every time I get the chiaquiles - so satisfying. We also branched out and got the carnitas tacos and they were room temperature including the pork.  Go early because they run out of items and the line can be really long at noon.
author: Karrot L.

description: These tamales are really amazing. I bought some from Whole Foods and I was hooked forever since. The masa dough is soft, moist and fragrant. The fillings are just lovely. Even the vegetarian one tastes wonderful. The mushroom and spinach one is my favorite.
author: Mona W.

description: Ehh overpriced fish tacos, and not really worth the wait.  Don't get me wrong it was good, but you can get these at any taco stand.  The fish was nicely fried and not too battered.  There is also plenty of lettuce.  The guac was good, the fish was okay.  Biggest problem is the taco is way too big for street food.  Gets way too messy.  I wish they made smaller fish tacos.
author: Terence N.

description:
How anyone can give this place less than 5 stars is beyond me.

We eat here literally every Saturday we are in town - have for years - get their tamales to make at home too.  I have NEVER had a meal here I would describe as anything other than excellent in years of eating here almost weekly.

The ceviche tostada when they have it is too good for words but our stand by are the Chilaqiles which are just perfection - pasture raised eggs - home made tortillas - chunks of avocado and mexican crema - a plate of insane goodness.

The aguas frescas are house made and pure fruit - I should know as we ordered large batches for a party recently and got the pulp then added water once we had them home - EVERYONE was raving about them - what a hit!
author: Mylea C.

description:
Delicious chiaquiles. Every time I've been here it's been really good. There's nothing quite like a steaming hot plate of beans, fried tortillas, eggs, and salsa or mole to get you moving on a Saturday morning. I've also tried the tamales and they're delicious too. 

Beware it's often crowded, you'll have to wait a bit, and there's usually only outdoor curb side seating.

Primavera's stand is one of the best Mexi-Cali places outside of the Mission.
author: Velshin C.

description:
I'm not even sure I can adequately express in words my love affair with their chilaquiles, but here goes.

I was introduced to this delicious breakfast dish sometime last year by my friend, a bay area native.  One taste and I was hooked.  For awhile, I made it my Saturday morning ritual to come to the Farmer's Market and get my chilaquiles fix.  But, like most things that taste this awesome, it just wasn't good for my waistline, so I've eased up a little on my obsession.

I've never tried anything else here, but I've heard the tamales are good (you can actually buy them at Whole Foods on Franklin).  I usually sub the refried beans for whole black beans (that's a whole different love affair in and of itself).  It's a bit pricey and you often have to wait quite awhile, but you can tell the ingredients are quality.  Like for most things at the Farmer's Market, you're paying for the atmosphere and the view of the Bay.  If you've got an extra 4 or 5 bucks to blow, try some of their refreshing beverage concoctions.
author: Laura C.

description:
S.B. and I eat at Primavera every Saturday.  We always order the special which changes every week.  So far, I've never been disappointed and I love being able to taste something new each time.  A couple things never change - the ingredients are fresh, based on what is in season at the time, and their masa is the best!  I'm pretty amazed that I haven't had one bad meal there to date.  (Wow...the fish tacos!  If you happen across this dish, it is a MUST).

In addition to ordering the weekly lunch special, we also take home a bag of tamales (love the butternut squash/cheddar the best), chips and salsa to eat during the week.  Only bad/good thing is, this food is fresh with no preservatives, so it won't last more than a week in the fridge without getting moldy.
author: Burrito M.

description:
Saturday mornings I'm known as Esmeralda at the farmer's market.  It is the name I give when I order the perfect fish taco, amazing chilaquiles, ridiculous chile relleno.  It has gotten to the point where people from the market just call me "Esmeralda".  

I can't say enough about the perfection that is the fish taco.  First can we start with a freshly made tortilla?  They press the tortilla right in front of you!  Then comes a hearty sauce and two perfectly deep-fried pieces of fish.  Next is the avocado cilantro crema topped with thinly sliced cabbage.  I could live off of these things!  

I've learned to order an half order of chilaquiles when I give into my cravings.  The eggs are soft scrambled, the tortilla chips are made by primavera and have a thick bite.  They are topped with crema, onions and chunks of avocado.  Everything is served with a side of beans - your choice of pinto, refried pinto, black and refried black.  I usually go for the refried black beans.  

Go and tell them Esmeralda sent you!
author: Monica L.

description:
I've been very hesitant to write this review because I don't want it to get anymore crowded than it already is, but I gotta lay it down and tell you the truth.  This is part of my Saturday morning ritual and I love it!  After an hour of spin class, I stroll over to Primavera and get my grub on.  I'm sure you're wondering what the heck brings me back to this place weekly when the Farmers' Market has so much to offer.  I'll tell you: if they have tacos of any kind that day, you better get it and get it early before it's gone because hands down it's going to be delicious!  Also, their verde chilaquilles is spectacular.  As for the tamales, I heart the spinach and mushrooms one.  It's all amazing and totally worth the wait which is always long if the day is sunny.  

Now that I have confessed my love for Primavera, if you see me in line behind you, just save me an order of the verde chillaquilles or the taco plate, ok?  Thanks in advance!

P.S. Minus 1 star for the fact that they're not the cheap Mexican food I'm used to.
author: Lisa R.

description:
The best chilaquiles in town, and some damned fine scrambled eggs on the side. They sell other things? Oh, right... yes, they also have some good tamales and... well, if they don't have chilaquiles, my Saturday is essentially ruined, so forgive me for not remembering the other stuff. ;)

Downsides: The long lines, and the limited hours. If this were a real restaurant, I'd have a hard time justifying breakfast anywhere else.

Update 7/14: Just tried their fish tacos for the first time: Mmmm-mmm!
author: anita c.

description:
Wow. Jean and I were at the Ferry Building Farmer's Market this past Saturday. The market opens at 8am, we were there at 8:15am and saw this long line at the Primavera booth. We got in line, without even really knowing what was in store for us. We just knew it HAD to be good. 

We ordered the tamale plate. It had two tamales, the pork tamale and the green chili tamale with some black re fried beans. It was honestly the BEST tamale & beans I ever had in my life. Sorry Georgina & Petra, this includes your homemade tamales. 

The beans had this incredible smokey flavor. Just great. We live about 90 miles from the City, but I have a feeling we will be returning soon for more of Primavera's divine food. WOW.
author: Rocky F.

description:
This place is amazing. I would get (have gotten) on a plane for the breakfast here at the Primavera tent on any Saturday morning of the farmers market.

Incredible tamales, black beans and eggs; all with salsa. It is really special and the vibe is, well, THE VIBE. What can one say...be there or be square.

I can't believe I have not reviewed this before - I just included it in a Farmers market review I guess??? Oh yeah - entire meal noted above: $6.50. You can't beat that with two sticks and a whisk.
author: J T.

description: Excellent tasting, though a tad small on serving size. Reasonable prices. The setting is beyond - the Bay Bridge, the SF Bay, the sights & sounds of a busy market. Oy! Sat morning in late fall had decent crowds & no long lines to complain about. People watching galore!
author: Candace V.

description:
I love Tamales...and Primavera's Tamales are fantastic!  During our last visit to San Francisco, I wanted to try something different from another vendor at the Farmer's Market.  I left feeling very disappointed that I had not ordered Tamales...There's always next time.

Pretty pricey, as most Farmer's Market goods are, but the plates are huge and the food is delicious.
author: Joanne N.

description:
Hard to miss this food stand since it always has a huge line.  Folks often write reviews and comment on whether the food is worth the money.  Since time can be considered money, those folks should factor in that premium into their calculations for Primavera because it will cost you a lot of time.  The food is pretty good, but I don't think it deserves the fanatical following.

Chilaquiles Verdes: Seems like a glorified nacho dish.  The nachos are awesome though, tasting freshly made and the green salsa gives them a good kick.  The refried beans are just refried beans and scrambled eggs are just scrambled eggs... kinda blah.  The soft avocado and sour cream gives some good personality.

Pozole Rojo w/ Pork Riblets: Love the red stew base and all the soft hominy.  The pork riblets in the name are deceptive because there was probably only one in the dish I got.  I definitely appreciate this dish because it doesn't seem prevalent at the Mexican joints around town.

Crispy Potato Taco: A Mexican samosa?  Came with the Pozole Rojo.  Definitely a first for me.  A nice, slightly spicy mashed potato wrapped in a deep fried corn taco folded in half.  I could definitely see this catching on in middle American along the lines of microwave taquitos.  Was a great when dipped in the pozole rojo, though didn't do a good job of absorbing much sauce.

Potato & Chorizo Sopes: Loved the corn base since it was thick enough to have a chewy inside between the fried outer edges.  The chorizo was extremely salty so I couldn't eat at such a rapid pace.  Good in small doses, definitely share this plate.
author: Adam B.

description: MMmmmm chilaquiles (or as my friend calls them, "nachos with red sauce") and pork tamales!!! And smother your plate with their salsa! It's great on everythinggggg :)
author: Mimi N.

description: Excellent Veg. taco, so fresh. The veg. taco is not on the menu, so you will have to ask them to create it. The tortilla is the best I've ever had. So glad I stopped here.
author: Lisa S.

description: Yowza. We got the shrimp and snapper tostadas and the chilaquiles. I think the chilaquiles are very good, though over rated by other yelpers. The tostadas though! So good. The flavors! The fish! The shrimp! I'm craving it so bad as I write this.
author: Trent M.

description: It must be a Bay Area thing, I've never heard of Chilaquiles growing up all over Southern California. But whatever it is, you just have to know that the chilaquiles here at Primavera (9.5) is very good. Just the right amount of sauce on top of fresh chips that hold their crunch. Wash down with a pineapple, hibiscus or strawberry agua fresca (3.75) a perfect way to start  a sunday at the farmers market.
author: Vince E.

description:
You just CAN"T miss eating at Primavera's stand at the Ferry Building during Saturday's San Francisco Farmer's market.  It's a love affair with food for the foodies out there.  You have to take in the enitre farmer's market experience if you enjoy food like I do!!!

Primavera is known for the tamales which are terrific but I just LOVE the Chilaquiles Aquascalientes and the Oaxacan Tlacoyos.  This place knows how to do food.

This is a breakfast of champions and you follow it up with a coffee from Blue Bottle Coffee.  Yum!!!
author: Jackie A.

description: Really liked the fish tacos and the ceviche tostada. The waters out of fruits were really good.
author: Guillermo M.

description:
EAT THIS.

EAT IT NOW.

The chilaquiles at Primavera are beyond righteous. This is easily the best Mexican breakfast I've ever had this side of the border. The tortillas used for the chips are thick, hearty, and rustic, and each bite unleashes an explosion of corn and peppery undertones that I've never experienced elsewhere. Then there's the aroma. Oh, the aroma. The chips have a subtle, loamy bouquet that reminds me of an earthen oven or wood chips from a smoker. Or maybe it's the sauce I'm smelling. Either way, I'm telling you, you gotta try it.

Although the eggs and beans are the real meat of this dish, it's the seasoning and condiments that make it so extraordinary. For starters, Primavera uses Guajillo chiles in the salsa, which I rarely find in the States and I think adds much subtler, and richer, taste than jalapeños. A similarly authentic note is provided by the cotija cheese, which, like parmesan, adds a nutty, dry note that compliments the eggs and avocado very well.

All in all, if you're ever near the Ferry Building on Saturday, you simply must give this a try.
author: Chris P.

description:
For the many times I've been at the SF Farmers' Market I've always passed up Primavera because of the long gringo lines. Yesterday I found the line to be incredibly short so I decided to give it a shot.

I was looking at the plates and wasn't too thrilled with the portions until I spotted the tamales. I ordered the tamale plate, 2 tamales with beans $9.50. I thought it was a bit steep for just tamales except I was craving some after seeing a tamale demo earlier in the week.

Without much wait the my order was ready. It looked quite good. I spooned some watery-salsa-whatever on my plate from the huge bucket-like vat. Taking a seat next to the gorgeous scenery helped make my meal so much better. What wonderful weather!

These tamales were awesome. For the past several years I've been turned off to tamales because people make the dry, crumbly, and bland kind. Primavera's on the other hand are moist, well formed, and tasty. There were two kinds of tamale. One was chicken with a green chile sauce and the other was mushroom vegetable with cheese. I like both yet the vegetable one was permeated with an addicting cheese flavor. I was impressed that each tamale's filling was very moist. The refried black beans were great too. It had a nice spicy kick to it.

____

I would definitely come back to try out some more dishes. I also hear that the drinks are awesome. I can't speak for anything else but the tamales.
author: Michael H.

description: Even though it's overstated, the chilaquiles are to die for! OMG I had the green sauce ones last weekend. I mean I love the red and I'm saying "How can it get any better?" Then they come out with the green and I'm like "Whoa this is how." Now It's got me thinking, "What's coming next? Yellow?" Wow think about that, yellow sauce!
author: Steve P.

description:
probably a 3.5, waited in a little line for chilaquiles (pricey)
Guajillo Chile Chilaquiles with house made Chorizo, organic,local scrambled eggs, refried beans, sour cream, avocado, queso cotija, onion and Cilantro -- tasted nice with salsa once mixed up, but didn't bring any special flavor, almost like just appealing to the masses.  also tried the beef barbacoa tacos which were good, classic verde and onion/cilantro
author: Rob C.

description:
My friend told me there's only one thing she goes to the Ferry Building Farmer's Market for-- the chilaquiles at the Primavera Mexican food stand. Apparently you have to get there earlier than their closing time (2pm) if you want any of the good stuff. We got there around 11:15 am and the line was a decent size.

Got my chilequiles ($9.50) and sat at a table right by the water, with the Bay Bridge just chillen in the background. What a beautiful view to go with a delicious breakfast on a sunny San Francisco day!

My food was wonderful. I wish the scrambled eggs were a little less soft (everyone has THEIR way of making eggs), but they were tasty nonetheless. The homemade tortilla chips smothered in beans and other Mexican deliciousness were to die for. Loved the avocado on top, and smothered the whole plate in their house made salsa.

One of the best breakfasts I've had in a while!
author: Ashley D.

description: Chilaquiles: I am pretty sure I'll have a hankering for this in the future. The fried tortilla with sauce coating is really good. The beans have a good flavor and would be awesome to have with some mexican rice (none avail that I can see.) The complementary salsa went well with my eggs. Enjoyed it thoroughly.The avocado and those fried tortilla chips with the sauce coating will what I will be going back for, for sure...
author: Vicki T.

description:
I saw this place featured on food network. I actually trekked over there on a gorgeous Saturday morning.

I was a bit disappointed when I saw the price and how much people were getting back in return. However, I decided to wait in line and try for myself.

I ordered:
1 Crispy Potato-Masa Pork Sopes "Colima" (Ground pork with potato, salsa verde, cabbage and radish)
