--I like the bread that these were on, however, I could barely finish one of them. It tasted good, but I wonder if there is a less greasy form of it. It was just too heavy. The topping was pretty good. After ordering this, I was hoping that the potatoes would be mixed in or the taste/ smell covered up -- which I am happy to report it was. [Smell, more than taste of potatoes make me nauseous].
 1 Jamaica drink
-- Was delicious, but I still don't think it was worth $3.75

This place is overpriced for the food you get. I love Mexican food, but I am not going to pay an arm and a leg for something I can get at a local taqueria, or a friend's place. 

I might come back again when the menus change and try something else.
author: Anisha G.

description:
I had the tamale, it's really good so I change my review. 
I got the non-dairy mushroom spinach, there's barely any spinach, it's like all mushroom, and I feel like I taste butter... 
I'm a little skeptical about how serious they are about labeling what they put in their tamale, and I wrote them and did not hear back, so... maybe I will stay away :(
author: 0 L.

description: A plate of Primavera's chiaquiles and a beautiful ocean view ... pretty much one of the best ways to spend Saturday morning in San Francisco. Despite the simple list of ingredients (tortilla chips, eggs, salsa, eggs, avocado, beans), it's not cheap, at nearly $10. But oh man, it's delicious. The tortilla chips are smothered in a spicy red sauce, yet manage to retain their crunch. The eggs are excellently scrambled, just cooked so that they're still soft. What you really want to do is eat everything in one bite, so scoop some beans and eggs onto a tortilla chip and enjoy. My one complaint is that I wish they gave a bit more eggs/bean and a little less chips for an improved ratio.
author: Ada T.

description:
Primavera, "Brexican", has been a Saturday tradition of mine and my two running partners for 12+ months now.  Although the line can appear long, it moves fast, and for $10 you get a kick ass authentic Mexican breakfast.  

Let's just say that on rainy days when Primavera doesn't show, the three of us go through withdrawals.
author: Kevin B.

description: I make it a point to go here on as many Saturdays as I can to get the tamales with mole sauce. They are amazing and I never can get sick of them. At times the sides are amazing (have pickled potatoes) and other times they are just merely good (no pickled potatoes). I think I tried something else a long, long time ago but never went back to it since I love the tamales so much. As with all good things, sometimes the wait can be brutal but it only makes the food taste so much better.
author: Miko L.

description:
if you're reading this on a Saturday morning, go RIGHT NOW to the Ferry Building, go to the Primavera booth at the back of the farmer's market, and get an order of the Yucatecan Panuchos (if you're lucky enough to find them on the menu).

It's a small handmade corn tortilla, split and stuffed with beans and hard boiled egg slices, then deep-fried, topped with meltingly-tender braised pork,  served with pickled onion and avocado slices.  

OMG.  never heard of this dish before -- it's a fantastic mix of flavors & textures ... go try it!!!
author: Jaina S.

description: Waited on the long line last Saturday on a visit to SF. It moved quick and food was worth it. My friend and I split the Chorizo & German butterball Potato Enchiladas topped with 2 poached eggs, w. refried beans, pickled chiles and guac. For $10 this generous portion was filling and enough for the both of us to share. The Pinapple Cucumber & Jamaica Aguas Frescas was fresh and cool perfect for balancing the heat of the enchiladas. Snag a bench or sit on a rail to enjoy your meal while overlooking the bay bridge.
author: Lizz K.

description:
i decided to wait in line and check this place out on possibly one of the busiest saturdays ever.  wait time was 20-30minutes. i ordered the chicken mole tamales and then the beer battered fish tacos.

i guess i should have ordered the tamale plate because all i got was one tamale. it was good.

the fish tacos were delicious though!  the best!  if i had known how good they were i wouldve ordered another plate instead of having 4 of us share the two on the plate.  i was supposed to share the one taco with my bf but i ate the whole thing before he came back.

oops
author: claudia y.

description:
I have been suspecting for a while that I have started on the wrong foot with Mexican food.  I have shun it for years thinking that I simply don't like it.  But as I embraced empanadas in Chile and drooled over Peruvian ceviches at La Mar and enjoyed all my meals very much in Spain, my husband asked why I wouldn't like Mexican food if I like other Latin food.  Hmmm.  Maybe I just never had good Mexican food before.  

Needless to say, I am far from being a Mexican food expert.  So I am not even sure what we had the other day at Primavera.  All I know is that we ran into our neighbors at the market and they tell us how much they like Primavera, and next thing you know, we lined up and ordered a plate ourselves.  

It had three tortillas with beef brisket toppings and hot sauce.  And it was really good.  Spicy and greasy. And really delicious freshly made tortillas.  

To save our mouths from burning, we ordered a atole to share.  It was like a variation on hot chocolate.  Perfect for an unusually gloomy and cold Ferry Building day.  

I wouldn't jump to say that I have been converted, but Primavera is a darn good place to start.
author: Candice B.

description:
The Ferry Building Farmer's Market is always such a big production. Move it, Lulu Lemon girl, I need my Blue Bottle. Mr. Tourist, scoot over, the grapefruit really can't be thaaat fascinating. Okay, okay, the crowds may be unavoidable since I seem to have a problem with getting there before 12. But seriously, can't a girl sleep in?

Primavera saved me from crankiness today, and reminded me why I go to the Ferry Buiding in the first place. The chilaquiles! I waited in a line of 20 to get to them, but I'm pretty sure I would wade through a vat of human excrement if that's what it took. These chilaquiles are pure home made deliciousness, with scrambled eggs, refried beans, saucy tortilla chips and a smathering of sour cream on top. 

They have a second table where you can pick up pre-made food to take home as well, and they have everything from guacamole to salsa to their famous stone ground corn chips. A package of tamales is $5, and if you're tired of the same old, they have some pretty exotic choices, like butternut squash & green chile and pumpkin & white cheddar.

In the end, I took my chilaquiles over to the little bench overlooking the ocean, tuned out the craziness and downed them happily with a Jamaican lime agua fresca. Primavera, you rock.
author: Nicole G.

description:
From my recent blog review...

"...Maybe it was eating our food under the bright morning sun with a crisp sea-breeze blowing across the water, and the impressive bay bridge in front of a cloudless sky dominating our view that made the chilaquiles taste so good; but likely it was because the thick, fresh-made and fried tortillas were incredibly tasty, and had a perfect crunch-to-sogginess ratio that is essential for good chilaquiles. The sauce was excellent too, and so was the rest of the plate: rice, beans, avocados and amazingly soft and fresh-tasting scrambled eggs. Really this is one of the better plates of chilaquiles I have ever had, and with their well-known hangover curing properties I could only look at my plate and wonder in vain, "Where were you the day after Thanksgiving?" The tamales on the other hand were a little dry and the masa fell apart too easily. The taste was good but my wife and I both fought over the rest of the chilaquiles while the leftover tamales got cold on the bench beside us as the boldly intrusive seagulls sat like vultures on a nearby railing, beady eyes fixed on the remains."
author: Mark M.

description:
I knew I had a five star review on my hands when I was torn away from the amazingness of the Roli Roti porchetta sandwich at the Ferry Building Farmers' Market.  On most Saturday mornings I am able to resist the giant line of patrons waiting for Primavera's Mexican delights in order to wait in the giant line of people who feel it is perfectly acceptable to eat a herbbed pork sandwich at 9:00 am (my kind of people).  However on this particular Saturday morning I could smell the delicious aroma of battered fried fish from stands away and came to realize that Primavera was offering fish tacos!

"Screw you pork sandwich" I thought to myself - I later apologized to Roli Roti in my head like a cheating husband to a devoted wife.  Anyway, I stood in line drooling over the promise of fish tacos in the morning, paid the nice lady and waited for my name to be called.  When I saw the plate of two heaping fish tacos I knew I was going to be happy.  Sure enough Primavera delivered and exceeded all of my fish taco expectations.  Perhaps the best part of these tacos is that the tortilla is so strong and pliable.  No wimpy thin tortillas that break in the center leaving the contents of your taco on the plate, these tortillas really stand up to the vast amounts of fish squeezed into the filling.  

I can't say that I am leaving my porchetta sandwich for good, we have too much of a history to throw it all away.  But every now and then I will have to see my Primavera fish tacos on the sly.
author: Dana H.

description:
This is my go-to place on Saturday mornings during the farmer's market at the ferry building.  Yes, believe it or not, I walk right past the Roli-roti porchetta line and head straight here. You have to keep walking past the ferry building on the right and past all the other vendors like Roli-roti and the Hog Island Oyster booth, come near the water and snake left a little bit.  Look for the line.  The star item on their menu is the chilaquiles.  Yes, when I first came, I thought $9.50 was insane for a plate of eggs that you get on a paper plate and have to eat while standing up or on a log.  

But then I had my first bite.  Wow, maybe it's the farm fresh eggs, maybe it's the fresh avocados and sour cream, maybe it's the thick, coated chips to eat your eggs on or the decadent refried beans, but I personally think it's the crack they must put in these eggs that make them so good!  You put some egg, some refried beans, some avocado and some salsa on these super thick chips and shove it in your mouth.  After a bit or two your plate starts looking like a mess but you won't care, you'll scrape the plate clean.

When the husband and I used to come, we used to get other plates, like the tamales but trust me, they don't compare.  Then we tried getting two plates of chilaquiles but that was alot so now we compromise on sharing a plate of the eggs and a an agua fresca and trying something else at the market.  Make sure you get there early.  I've been a few times by noon or 1pm or so and they are out of the chilaquiles.  Also, a slight negative is that they let you put on the salsa to your own liking but they've engineered it with a shallow wooden spoon and a tall container so that you can only get like a tsp of salsa per scoop.  I personally am not fazed so I'll stand there and take 10 scoops while people wait but just wanted to warn the faint of heart.  Trust me, the salsa is worth it.  Make sure you have enough!
author: Susan L.

description: Tasty, but had the runs the WHOLE DAY after eating here at the Sunday farmer's market.... very suspicious as I had something vegetarian. It was probably the sour cream that was not refrigerated appropriately.
author: Bootylicious J.

description:
Love love LOVE their tamales. Definitely on the pricey side as far as tamales go ($4.50 each or $9.25 for a plate of two with a side of delicious black beans) . . . but also definitely on the yummy side as far as tamales go.

Sadly, I only get to have Primavera on the Saturdays I actually have cash left after browsing the rest of the farmer's market. :)
author: Cynthia T.

description:
O Primavera, why are you not at the Ferry Building on Tuesday and Thursday?  Why are you not at the Ferry Building every day?  Why are you not in the ground floor of my apartment building?  I would eat your food every day, multiple times a day.

I had lunch at the Primavera stand around 11am today, and I am seriously considering returning at 2pm for second lunch, not because I'm hungry, but because I want to try the German butterball potato tacos.

Sure, the two tamale plate is $9.50, but it is a HEAP of food and it is SO delicious.  They've even started throwing in some pickled vegetables on the side (cauliflower, potato, carrot, jalapeno) without raising the price.  I usually have some room left after the taco or tostada plate, but not after the tamales.  Even so, I ordered an extra butternut squash tamale just for my 20-month old son, because he loves them too!

The folks running the stand are friendly and they keep the line moving.  Sure, there are lots of other stands at the market, but I know I'll always be happy here.
author: Connie K.

description: I have no idea how this place has such high ratings- if anyone has ever been to a taco truck or a decent burrito place in the mission. The only thing I could think of is a number of tourists go here and find the food good versus a Chipotle back home.  When I saw the prices, I thought you would get 2-3 tacos, but it was actually for one taco! And it was nothing special compared to a taco truck in East Oakland or a place in the Mission. Avoid this place....
author: Jim B.

description:
Ok, so since the chilaquilles were SOLD OUT on Saturday (got there around 1:30pm), my only other option were the tamales...OMG, SO GOOD! The pork and the chicken---YUM!

Oh how I love you Primavera!
author: Misha F.

description:
Scrumptious and Delumptious!

Whenever my gf and I have a chance to go to the farmer's market in SF, we go here for breakfast.

Primavera has awesome breakfast plates.  I don't know what it is, but it just tastes good.  

The drinks can be a hit or miss though.
author: Johnny C.

description: I am absolutely addicted to their Tortillas, their Salsa and Guac. I can usually find the salsa and tortillas in stores like Real Foods or the Marina Super..however, I can only get the Guac at the Famers Market. So worth the trek each Sat am!
author: Mimi T.

description:
I LOVE THE CHILAQUILES!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Why? 
All the ingredients are fresh and made with love. 
The portions are large for a price of nine dollars.
It is definitely worth it
Imagine eggs, yummy black beans instilled with garlic, sprinkled with queso fresco, corn tortilla chips slathered with red poblano mole, cream, fresh avocado to top it off. I had it for breakfast and I'm still full!
Good customer service, clean stand with a great view of the bridge on a sunny day at the Farmer's Market. I'd be happy to get another bit of that stuff next time. holla!
author: J A.

description:
Pretty tasty food but I agree, it's fairly overpriced. It was fun to try it but I certainly wouldn't make a habit of it. The wait sucks too, as the Ferry Building Farmers Market is a mob scene of epic proportions. 

Tried the chilaquiles plate ($9) which comes with organic scrambled eggs and whole black beans along with some decent chunks of avocado on top. The chicken mole tamale (solo, not the plate) was about $4 and not particularly impressive. The masa to meat ratio was decent but I didn't taste anything resembling mole sauce in that tamale. The shrimp and red snapper ceviche tostadas were the star of breaky, two to an order at $9 also. These had excellent flavor, the shrimp and snapper mixed with some salsa fresca and lime crema on top of crispy shells. Very delicious.

Trekking from the Mission to hit this place up? Probably only gonna happen once!
author: margot b.

description:
Delicious!

The chorizo/egg dish, fried tacos, chilaquiles, fresh corn tortillas, etc are all must tries... wasn't terribly crazy about the tamales (pumpkin was too sweet for me).

Yes, considering it's a food stand it's on the pricier side ($9 for most dishes) but I believe for the quality it's worth it... try getting there earlier because they start running out of food by 11:30/Noon.
author: Nenette Y.

description:
Simply Delicious. I got lucky with a short line, and was lucky to have a great Saturday brunch. The Tamales rocked. What was already sold out looked to have rocked too. Not having a line rocked. The chipotle salsa rocks, and I am now also addicted to it. I picked it up once at a Mollie Stones, and it has taken business from my usual fresh salsa splurge suspect Casa Sanchez, also an awesome salsa in its own right. It would be great if I could find the Primavera salsa n the city at other markets too. 
Straight and simple, if your at the Ferry Building on Saturday and are craving authentic high quality California Mexican food, it's probably worth the line, and its good for the money.
author: Adam S.

description:
I write this review for one thing and one thing only... CHILAQUILES!!! I plan trips and flights around the farmers market so that I can get the chilaquiles from the Primavera stand for breakfast. The fried tortillas are like crack they're so good. Then throw on the egg, salsa, avocado, and red sauce... DONE, I am done and gone to heaven. The refried black beans as a side are great too topped with cotijo cheese.

I have no idea about the other food they serve***, as far as I'm concerned, if you didn't order the chilaquiles then you ordered the wrong thing and your life will be that much less fulfilling until you do.

***I've actually tried both of the tamales as a misguided individual did order them once and offer me some. They are a good choice and very filling, if you have some foolish aversion to taking good advice and ordering the chilaquiles.
author: Dave A.

description: I had the mole tamales here and they were AMAZING! Also, try the Chilaquiles Guanajuato which I consider the breakfast of champions. You can't beat a better Saturday morning then munching down some RoliRoti followed by amazing tamales!
author: Steve K.

description: Holy moly!  Every single plate coming out of this place looked and smelled heavenly.  Excellent chilaquillas!!!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Rejoice--finally a fish taco worth celebrating! On a beautiful Saturday morning, make your way to the Primavera Mexican food stand at the Ferry Bldg. Farmers Market.

The menu at  the Primavera changes every week, with staples being a variety of their tasty tamales, but the best, absolute finger-lickin'-best I've had are their fish tacos. Unfortunately, it's the luck of the draw on their menu, but rest assured, everything is good there. I've also had their ceviche tostadas, several tamales, huevos rancheros, carnitas, and chilaquiles--all damn good. 

Beware: GO EARLY. If you stroll there anytime after 11:30 am, you will see their big white menu with a lot of black X's through the best offerings--even their agua fresca runs out early, and then you will feel compelled to compensate by going to Mijita's, at which point you will surely be disappointed. 

If you can't make it to the Farmers Market, Sonoma-based Primavera's tamales are available at Whole Foods and a few other stores. I recommend butternut squash and cheese...
author: Dora A.

description:
Saturday's only, but it's the best (brunch) thing going at Ferry Plaza. I get the chilaquiles and my kids eat the scrambled eggs while I eat everything else :-) Great agua fresca too. 

If you like food stand mexican but want less of a crowd (or less $$), check out El Huarache Loco and/or the pupusa experts at the locals-only Alemany market.
author: y k.

description:
These are the chilaquiles you've been looking for! Since that trip to Puerto Vallarta three years ago, I've been searching for chilaquiles that might come close to rivaling the fresh, lovingly prepared, neatly presented dish we found in Mexico. Primavera has it. Oh and those eggs - must've been laid the same day - fluffy, yellow, flavorful!

Primavera is worth the wait in line and the melon juice is totally unique. The only unpleasant thing is nudging everyone in the crowded Sat. morning Farmers Market environment and then trying to find a place to savor this great breakfast.
author: maureen f.

description:
Yeah, it's a little overpriced but this is the Farmer's Market, right?...EVERYTHING is overpriced here because, let's face it, they should call it the 'Shi Shi' Farmer's Market because no farmer does it this posh unless it's in Switzerland.

But there is some great food to be had here if you want a reprieve from Hayes Street Grill or Rose Pistola.

The chorizo scrambled eggs with black beans and avocado was sooo simple but incredibly tasty...Apparently, they change up their menus pretty regularly so you can't predict what will be there from week to week but it's quality food.

Chiliquiles apparently is the 'popular' choice but definitely prefer the chorizo scramble...Still, ya can't go wrong with this one either.

Their drinks are what got me to try their food in the first place, also something that changes on a regular basis...The fresh rasberry lemonade is pretty remarkable and I can't wait until they have it again.

If you venture to Farmer's Market and don't have the cash to spend it at the oyster bar (I mean, what Farmer's Market doesn't have an oyster bar, right?) then you'll survive with an occasional treat at Primavera...You WON'T be disappointed.

BTW, do they have a brick and mortar establishment anywhere?...I wish...Apparently, they are going to be opening, soon, a store in Sonoma but come on people, open up a restaurant for daily service in SF!
author: Barca F.

description: Brunch never tasted so good.  Food stand mexican food at the farmers market isn't supposed to be this yummy.  Farm fresh scrambled eggs, tender pork, and fresh pressed tortillas.  Excellent!  The service was extraordinarily friendly as well.  They even let me split my order to have half pork taco and half chilaquiles verdes (green goodness).  Best of all, a great dining room with a view (bench overlooking the water).  Hungry at the market?  Don't miss Primavera!
author: Tripp W.

description:
What's up with the name?
Does anyone know?  Seems odd for a Mexican spot.

Hands down the best Mexican breakfast with an amazing view...
I always go for the tamale plate $9
Choice of two served with pinto beans and side salad.
Summer squash, mixed vegetables or chicken.  I always go for what's in seasonal and the veggie option.  The masa is perfection!!!

Never fails BFF goes for Chilaquiles verdes -hardy portion and before I can ask for a bite... it's spoon scrapping gone.  "BFF, Where the Love?"  Guess when it comes to outstanding taste one becomes selfish.

To drink they offer a variety of lemonades,  good tasting but I'd save my money and you should go to Drinkwell Soda if you haven't yet :)  It's a fizzy tonic --that's good for you.

btw Tony Borudain ate here!!! hee hee
author: phong-lan h.

description: There isn't a thing on this menu that I wouldn't love to eat. I personally had the chilaquiles and my husband had the pork tamale. If you haven't tried chilaquiles, please consider tortilla chips and scrambled eggs, topped with a spicy sauce and everything good. It will make your morning/afternoon so much better. They also sell refreshing juice drinks to counter the heat of the food. Wonderful stand in the Farmer's Market!
author: Stacy G.

description:
My Mom was in town this weekend from freezing cold Minnesota and on Saturday I just had to take her to the Ferry Plaza Farmer's Market.  We arrived fashionably early as the weekend crowds can become uncomfortably unbearable as the hours pass.

Mom couldn't help but want to try the "place with the long line" aka Primavera.  We waited for 10 minutes at the stand to get our carnitas.  The guacamole was excellent and the pork was incredible.  There was not an ounce of fat to be seen for miles, yet the meat was amazingly tender.  

The staff gave the appearance that they were having a great time and the woman taking orders was very friendly and service-oriented.  Can't wait to stop by again soon.  For the price, the portions were generous and filling.  We shared a plate for "breakfast" (it was 9:00 am for heaven sake!) and didn't eat again (save for a few cheese cubes) until lunch!
author: Lindsay M.

description:
Oh yeah, this place deserves 5-stars alright.  I had a Saturday morning to kill at the Ferry Building and heard about this place.  The chilaquilles really hit the spot, especially on a cold and gloomy morning.

And get this- Anthony Bourdain stood in line and ordered the exact same thing I did 5 minutes after me!  I'm guessing he was there filming for an upcoming episode.  You might even get a chance to see me for a second or two since it looked like the cameraman was filming my gaping pie hole.  Just look for the guy sitting by the pier inhaling his chilaquilles and that would be me!
author: Kurt N.

description: This is one of the best places that serves mexican food. Their chicken green chili  tamales is one of its kind.
author: Sulaiman B.

description:
Their chilaquiles is the only reason I drag my ass out of bed on Saturday mornings.


A tip: if they are making something with tortillas that day, you can ask for a couple of them to go with your chilaquiles.

OK, one more tip: Ordering line on the left. People eagerly awaiting their food on the right.
author: Mister X.

description:
Oh, chilaquile and tamales, how you make my Saturday mornings...

When my boyfriend goes to the Roli Roti stand to get the pork sandwich (also VERY good but a little too meaty for me in the mornings), I go to Blue Bottle and Primavera.  I love the pumpkin with white cheddar tamales at Primavera, and if they don't have those (they have two different tamale types every week) then I go with the chilaquiles.  

The line can get a little long, but what do you expect--it's the Ferry Building farmer's market.  The last time I went the line was just intolerably long and I didn't have a half hour to spare, so I got the four pack of the pumpkin tamales to go.  Good buy and then I could enjoy them for the next week!  MMMMMMM.
author: Lindsay L.

description: A morning that involves chilaquiles AND masa cakes???  Perfection.  I've had a couple of other items during other trips to SF, but that may just be my ideal breakfast.
author: Betty R.

description: I seem to be attracted to places with a long line! This is worth the wait and madness of the farmer's market! Amazing quality and taste. Chilaquiles are the bomb. Awesome tamales. We buy their chips regularly now at Whole Foods. Treat yourself to this jem. It is a unique experience in SF.
author: Malarie J.

description: In between all my other meals at the ferry market, I stopped here for a tamale (sweet potato).  The texture and consistency were spot on with a nice flavor.  Definitely a nice place to have meal or a snack, judging from the long lines (breakfast ensembles seem most popular).
author: Andrew S.

description:
Seriously, I dont understand why everyone raves about this place.  My friend had Pork Tacos and I had Pork Tamales.  They were just o.k.  Both us agreed tacos from El Tonayense Taco Truck are waaay better.  
Be careful with your money, the cashier guy swindled us.  
Pork Tacos plate $9.50 + Single Pork Tamale $4.50.  He charged us $17.75.  By the time we realized this, it was too late.
author: Gelato G.

description: This place is great! It's too bad they only exist once a week behind the ferry building. The Chilaquiles are amazing!
author: Michael C.

description:
Love it some of the best Mexican food I have tasted in the states.

The beans are yummy.
The Egg dishes are great and the the salsa is fresh and tasty.

Great view when you eat outside.
author: Joe R.

description:
By far the best mexican food in the city.  Might be the best breakfast in town, too.  The difference is clear: this food is made with L-O-V-E.  Every item is at its best, and the revolving menu offers many  items that are rarely seen outside Mexico (like Tlacoyos).  The black beans are to die for (and might kill you, methinks the secret is lard). Fish tacos are worth getting up early for.  Love the ChiChi Rodriguez and the other Aguas, in many unusual flavors like Cucumber-Lime.

Of course, it's expensive, but the ingredients are only the best, and the view is worth a million bucks!
author: Teal H.

description: Chilaquiles every Saturday morning. That's my ritual. Even my kids love it. I'm sure everything else on the menu is good too, but in 4 years i haven't bothered to try. Gotta get my chilaquiles fix. Tip for those with kids, ask for a kids side of eggs and avocado (can also get tortillas, beans) and they'll charge you $1 or $2 for a giant boat of food. Hibiscus ice tea is delicious.
author: RK L.

description: Oh Saturday morning. No alarm, just waking up when I can't sleep anymore and have had my fill. Then walking down to the Ferry Building and weaving the crowds to my favorite temporary food establishment. These chilaquiles are one of my favorite meals in the city. The beans are perfect. The eggs might be the best i've ever had. The chips still crunchy. The gravy perfect. And lay down the salsa for that extra kick. So good.
author: Wes K.

description: I have yet to try this restaurant (I live near LA), but my coworker is related to the owner and brought in some of their tamales. So far they are the best tamales I have ever enjoyed!  The masa is delicious, moist, and full of flavor. The filling, organic butternut squash and cheese, was the perfect combination!  I can't wait to visit Primavera and also the sister restaurant El Molino Central.
author: J C.

description:
Note, the only star off is for price. It is overpriced.  9$ for Mexican is too much. 

However, for food quality and taste, it is outstanding! Fresh corn tortillas being pressed and grilled right before your eyes. The guacamole was lite and fluffy with just the right amount of lime. The chicken soft and tender. I wanted to try everything on the menu and panicked at the last second. Now, I can't wait to go back and try something else. 

Reminds me of the quality of Tu y Yo back home in Boston. If you have been there, you know what I am talking about.
author: Scott T.

description:
My friend Annie is a regular on Saturday mornings at the Ferry Building and says that Primavera has lines every weekend. Now I know why - best chicken tamale I've ever eaten, hands down. And the portion sizes are huge. I ordered the combo plate with black beans and an aguas frescas. The line moves quickly but it is kind of chaotic. The staff is super nice. 

If you find a better tamale, let me know.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Dear Primavera Staff:
Please get rid of the ridiculous wooden salsa spoon.  We need a ladle.  
Thanks.
author: Caroline O.

description:
I had the chicken mole tamale with a side of black beans. I will definitely return for the "breakfast of champions" egg dishes the other yelpers speak of. The tamale was delicious, but they could work on the presentation.
I was also unhappy with the service. They took our order in a robotic way, then our food sat getting cold even though we were waiting close by.
I think getting there early is the key!
author: Kyla L.

description:
Among the greatest advantages of living in San Francisco is to roll out of bed on a Saturday morning, throw on some clothes, and head to the Ferry Plaza Farmers Market to get chilaquiles from Cocina Primavera.  The fresh tortillas, the generous cuts of avocado, the buttery eggs, and the great refried beans are the perfect start to a weekend.  

Of course, everything else on the menu is great.  I also recommend the tamales and the ceviche if you tire of the chilequiles, but how could you ever get tired of this goodness?  

Seriously, the next Saturday you can, get to the Ferry Plaza, go all the way to the back and look for the yellow umbrella and the line of people.   Get in that line and pull out your $9.50 to have an amazing eating experience.  

Of course, if you can't make it to the Ferry Plaza, you can pick up the tamales at Whole Foods in the Bay Area (don't know about elsewhere).  You can also pick up the packaged tortillas with cotija cheese, or the wonderful salsa at the stand as well.  

But seriously, you need the chilaquiles.
author: Greg K.

description: I am rather surprised by the abundance of 4 & 5 stars.  It may very well be the best hot food at the Ferry Terminal Building's farmers market  (excluding the Slanted Door) and there may be some emotional attachment (and hype) because it has the only long line outside of a truck stall -- its food is realistically only a 2.0 star.  Those who haven't ventured onto and around 24th Street in the Mission have no basis for comparison.
author: K G.

description:
i don't even like mexican food but the chlaquile is delicious. this has become my weekend rountine

the grapefruit fresher is also really good.
author: Scarlet S.

description:
Primavera is pretty amazing. 

Like most Farmer's Market fare, it is a little pricey for what you get, but it's immediately evident the ingredients are of genuine quality. Mm. I recommend their aguas frescas and their roasted green chile and corn tamales. 

I'm a New Mexican transplant, and this is pretty much the closest you can get to a real Albuquerque green chile tamale in San France. Yummm.
author: Ryan S.

description: The chilaquiles at Primavera are amazing. The eggs are always cooked to perfection. The chips are amazing. The salsa brings it all together. It's a Saturday morning treat.
author: Sid M.

description: Chilaquiles!!! with several drops of chile just to make you feel more alive. Love them!! Craaave them!!!
author: Valerie A.

description:
This is one of my favorite things about sf. set at the back side of the ferry plaza farmer's market, primavera never fails to disappoint. 

first the chilaquiles are incredible. the chips are just spicy enough, the beans are pureed to perfection, eggs at the ideal hardness (not too hard), generous portions of avocado, crema and a little taste of cheese. i dream of these all week long.

you need to get there early before they run out of the daily specials.

everything is organic-- including the masa for the handmade fresh tortillas-- which is hard to find. 

tamales are also worth buying for a week of quick, flawless dinners. 

also, pick up the salsa to go. perfect fire roasted spicy flavors. it is cheaper at the market than at most stores. 

very sweet owners and daughter are always very excited and proud to serve you their delicious creations. i can't wait until they open their restuarant... in sonoma. boo!
author: Mara G.

description: delicious!  I love their ceviche & their tamales.  It's what I usually get for breakfast at the farmer's market - worth the wait in line!
author: Stacy A.

description:
Tortillas are handmade onsite and taste like corn!

My boyfriend, a Mexico City native, usually orders the chilaquiles plate - and he doesn't even like eggs all that much!

Posole that is sometimes on the menu during winter is so deliciously comforting!

Tlacoyos and tinga are things gringos won't see at an ordinary Mexican restaurant, but definitely worthy trying. Primavera does both very well!

Tried a berry-lime-mint agua fresca once that was really refreshing!

Boyfriend (who can eat A LOT) and I always leave stuffed - portions are great!
author: A. M.

description: Primavera is a great place to grab breakfast while rolling around the Farmers Market on Saturday. The egg dish with tortillas, avo, black beans and chorizo was perfectly cooked. Everything at the market is pretty pricey so the $9 bones isn't outta line. Plenty of seating out by the pier to kick it and get your grub on.
author: Phil M.

description: Walk around farmers market with a plate of Primavera chilaquiles and you will be the star of food envy.
author: Wakako U.

description: This is one of the few places that has helped me discover tamales. SO GOOD. The butternut squash was a real treat. I will never forget it.
author: Marian C.

description: Organic, fresh, uber-filling, beautiful plates of Cal-Mexican breakie & lunch glory on the waterfront on a Saturday morning.  Chilaquiles with massive chunks of avocado, perfect black beans with queso fresco, and light fluffy happy chicken scrambled eggs, freshly made corn tortillas.  Still one of my favorite breakfasts at the market, and I'm there all the time...
author: Melanie C.

description: Chilaquiles!!!!!!!!  The only reason I like coming to the Ferry Market when it's rainy is because the wait isn't as long for Primavera.  Their tamales are also good.  Will one day try the fish tacos, each time I think I want to I just end up heeding the siren song of the chilaquiles.
author: MJ C.

description: The chilequiles at the Primavera booth at Farmer's Market are the best I've ever had and probably my all-time favorite breakfast anywhere -- perfectly cooked, the right amount of sauce, chips, cheese, and eggs, and a definite spicy kick.  Rain or shine, it's always a fun, community scene -- dogs, kids, performers, the farmer's market, and that bay view right on the water.   The line moves pretty quickly and is part of the fun.  A perfect SF moment every time and a great way to start a Saturday.
author: Paul H.

description:
You beat me to it!  Been coming here since the plaza reopened--order whatever they have on the menu and be transported.  Their guacamole is outstanding, I've eaten tamales, fish tacos, huevos rancheros.  Also be sure to try whatever agua fresca they have--it's never too sweet, and always made from fresh fruit.  Each time I go to farmer's market I swear I'll try something else, but then I...just....can't....pass....it....up.  

How many days until Saturday????
author: Mel B.

description: When I see a long line, I naturally assume that it's because something awesome is occurring.  In the case of Primavera, it is the chilaquilles and they are deserving of the wait.  And really, the wait wasn't all that bad.  These people are pros and it shows.
author: Lauren L.

description: The first time I went to the Ferry Building Farmers Market, I was amazed at all the food options that are available.   I also noticed this one food stand that had a loooong line.  My thought process "If there's a line.. it's gotta be good."     I had just come back from Mexico and fell in love with those authentic carne asada tacos and lo and behold, Primavera was serving those that day.  $9 for two tacos might seem a lil pricey but once you dig into their tacos, it's worth it.  Their menu changes every week but I have not been disappointed anytime.   They are only open Saturdays.   Add my name to the list of people who want them to open a full-time restaurant.
author: Herb C.

description: Chilaquelas are insanely good. The chicken tamales are ok.
author: Christopher L.

description: If I had to rate my favorite place to eat in SF, it would be the Primavera stand at the Farmer's Market. Their tamales are the best I've ever had but I never get them because there's always something more enticing like shrimp & snapper ceviche, butterball potato tacos, masa cakes with chorizo and quesa fresca. If you ever visit Ferry Building Farmer's Market, this is a must.
author: Bill R.

description: Amazing huevos rancheros (Stone ground organic corn tortillas topped with frijoles colado, poached eggs and sikil p'ak (mayan pumpkin seed habanero pesto) and avocado! Sweet heavens, baby! Can't believe I had not try this heavenly dish before....I've been missing a lot...sigh. The Maurilia's pork tamale was very tasty too. There is usually a line but it's very well worth the wait. Get your food, sit at the table or bench and take in the bay view while enjoying the scrumptious goodies!
author: Yan M.

description: Ordered their two tamale combo - chicken + mushroom with cheese, which came with a side of black beans.  Unlike past encounters with tamales from a truck, these were moist, piping hot, and didn't fall apart.  The beans too were hardly an afterthought.  One of the cheapest and fastest meals you're likely to have at the SF Farmer's market.
author: Jeremy C.

description: Delectable goodness that's worth the long lines and high prices. 4.50 for a tamale? worth every penny! you never know what you will get, and you'd better go early or they'll be sold out. the best deal is to get two tamales and then you can get beans too. this is one of my favorite stops at the farmer's market, and you can eat it in the shadow of the bay bridge.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Yum yum.

I was shocked to find such fresh, light and delicious Mexican food at the Farner's Market.  The best part is that I don't live too far away.  I can just roll out of bed, throw on something comfy and mozie on down.  The first time I ate their food, I had something so yummy, but the name escapes me completely because no Mexican restaurant I have ever been to has served these.  They were basically corn and black bean cakes topped with chorizo and sliced raddish.  Shockingly deelish.  I went back today and was very bummed that the menu had completely changed.  I wondered if Primavera might disappoint.  I ordered the chilaquiles, which came topped with avocado and sour cream and a side of buttery scrambled eggs and the best black refried beans ever.  Their food sounds heavy but it is surprisingly light.  I have a sensitive tummy and tend to eat on the healthy side, but their food is perfect for me--hearty, not nauseating.

Although I don't expect to be paying $9.50 for food at any kind of food stand, they give you plenty of food for $9.50.  No tax and tip...it's still cheaper and tastier than any brunch around.

This is going to be my weekly Saturday habit.  I work in the area and wish they were there for the Tuesday farmer's market!
author: Kandi K.

description: I couldn't resist the long lines so I had to try it myself.  This was my first time eating chilaquiles, and they weren't bad (liked the eggs and chorizo) but I got tired of the tortilla triangles the meat was served on.  I actually preferred the tamales more - the pork was good, and the chicken mole was okay (I also got tired of the mole sauce).  Super fast from order to pickup, though, which I appreciated.
author: Melinda C.

description:
there are two places you *must* try while at the ferry plaza farmer's market.

the first is boulette's.  sure -- it's a pain to get in there and sample the grub, but it's worth the wait.

the second is primavera.

there's usually a long-ish line to get fed at their booth.  damn right there's a long line.  the food is fantastic.  it's easily the best food being served at any of the booths during market days.

had the chilaquiles plate today.  I'm sort of a light eater (preferring to sample a little of everything, but without a huge appetite).  I ate every damn bite of what I was served though.

it's well-worth spending 10 minutes in line.
author: Mark B.

description: Hands down, my favorite breakfast in the city.  Yes, you have to wait in line.  Yes, it's difficult to find a table, or part of a table, if it's sunny outside.  But, it's worth it.  I always struggle between the egg choice or the non-breakfast/lunch options, but the beauty of this stand is that you don't have to make a choice!  You can always do half orders (for half the price)!!!  The agua frescas are yummy and perfectly complement the food.  Everything is freshly made.  The chilaquiles, huevos rancheros, pork carnitas, fish tacos - EVERYTHING IS FANTASTIC!!!  I can't say enough wonderful things about this little food stand except - when will they open a full-time restaurant?!!
author: Christina S.

description: Yes, the food is good, but the prices are so high, I mean, come ON people, $9 for a tamale plate?  That is ridiculous, not to mention, that their best menu offering, fish tacos, is rarely on the menu.  I used to love Primavera and go there every week, but I am kind of over the huge line of tourists and Ferry Building Farmer's Market prices.   Not to give away my secret, but save your money and go to the Alemany Farmer's market-it's not as pretty, but you'll get 4 tamales for the price of 2 of the Primavera ones.
author: Rachel F.

description: Primavera has recently become one of my favorite weekend treats to myself.  I love heading down to the Ferry Building early on Saturday...ideally before 10...for breakfast.  I've been twice and had the chilaquiles both times.  They are sooooo good!  The eggs are fluffy and buttery.  The verde sauce is great.  My absolutely favorite part of the meal is the chips once they get a little bit soggy.  I tried the Aqua Fresca - the 3 citrus -  and it was amazing.  I ordered a small and immediately regretted not getting the large.  It is a bit expensive but it is worth every penny.
author: Julie P.

description: Tamales. Yes, get them. Really enjoyed the chicken mole...Punchy flavor, soft texture to the meet.........My husband who claims he doesnt' like tamales wouldn't really let me eat that many bites. Yummy beans (for better or worse). Just a warning, on a good day, there will be a line.
author: Jeannette L.

description: People had been telling me about the famous tamales at the market on embarcadero, so I finally decided to try them out. I had the best tamales of my life at Primavera! Seriously, maybe butternut squash tamales sound weird, but they were delicious! I got the two tamales plate and chose one beef and one butternut squash and next time I go I will be getting two butternut squash tamales. The plate also comes with beans and pickled vegetables. The pickled vegetables might look weird, but try them, they are tasty.
author: Carly W.

description:
i have gone to the farmers market many many times, but this saturday i finally went to primavera...the line is usually too long i don't want to wait.  however, the line goes by fast and it is worth it!

i got the breakfast plate and it was amazing! they have these chips that are still crispy but smothered in some sauce that makes them delicious! the eggs were hands down some of the best i have ever had!  they even include some yummy fresh avocado.  i would definitely go back and wait in line for this!  a little pricey, but oh so yummy!
author: Yummy E.

description: In my opinion, there's absolutely no better way to start a Saturday  in San Francisco than with a trip to the Ferry Building Farmer's Market and enjoying a chilaquiles breakfast washed down with a aqua fresca and followed up with a cup of Blue Bottle coffee.  I swear, It just doesn't get better than that!
author: Jeremiah A.

description:
This is some of the area's best Mexican food, period. They use fresh, high quality ingredients prepared with skillful recipes that do far more justice to what Mexican cooking is all about than most any of the sit down places in the Mission. All ingredients are top notch, including the masa they use for tamales and the fresh made tortillas, the best you're going to eat anywhere. Forget all this talk about the prices being too high. If you want Safeway quality eggs, meat, veggies, cheese and old tortillas, then go get something cheaper and less tasty somewhere else. This is good quality, real food. The prices are more than reasonable.

Eat there and enjoy. And when the little voice in your head tells you that this isn't "real" Mexican food, tell it to shut up. The voice will be wrong.
author: Jim S.

description: I fly in to San Francisco at least three times a year to get my chilaquiles fix.  Worth the wait, worth the price-fabulous.
author: Melissa M.

description: AWESOME beer-battered fish tacos (unless you hate mayonnaise ... there is definitely mayo involved). I've had some excellent tamales here, too.
author: Midori S.

description: This place is highly overrated as are their prices... We wanted to give this place a fair shake and therefore have tried it at least three different times and it's simply not that good tasting or worth the money....over 9 dollars for a tamale and small scoop, no I mean mini scoop of refried beans.. which turns out was probably a godsend since they were so terribly salty... Also, the guy working the front (some nerdy looking guy) was trying to impress some girl he kept referring to as "farmer's market girl" instead of paying attention to his paying customers. Anyway, we get the food and I was shocked.. the plate was handed over and I truly thought they made a mistake and left food off.. They presented us with what looked liked a half eaten tamale (mind you, tamales already aren't too big to begin with) a tablespoon of beans and 1/2 cup of some type of slaw.... To boot, the tamale was cold.... all this my friends for over 9 dollars.. to me , this is one of those places where you don't have true ethic food going on.. you have perhaps some person who thinks they know good food.. if this person worked with Mexican Cuisine, it sure doesn't show... The food was all sub-par and so not worth the money. Again, we have now tried this place a few times and it's just not up to snuff... Go to the Mission District and you can get better food and at lower prices.. Also note, the photos for this place do not match what you actually get........
author: Susan L.

description: Primavera just created a lifelong devotee.  The hubster and I were spending a weekend in SF to celebrate our anniversary (4 years of wedded bliss and 9 years total togetherness!)  and I really wanted to check out the farmers market at the ferry building.  Food stand after stand had us oohhing and ahhhing after all the baked goods, veggies and fruits.  Then my hubster saw this stand with an incredibly long line and saw that people were coming away with these fantastic looking plates of mexican food.  We kept walking to see if there was anything else that we wanted to eat, but once the hubster saw that mexican plate, he was adamant that we have our own mexican plate.  So we stood in line, which wasn't so bad, maybe 10 minutes.  Menu is very limited, so we went with the tamale plate which consisted of 2 tamales, side salad and side of beans.  They had a pork tamale with green chile sauce and a tamale with summer squash and cheese.  We opted to have one of each tamale for our plate.  Got our plate within a few minutes of ordering and found the quickest bench we could find so we could get our grub on.  That first bite was just awesome (my mouth is watering right now as I type this).  I first tried the summer squash and cheese tamale and was so impressed with how tasty it was.  I must say that I'm a masa lover.  I could care less about the filling because I'm just looking to savor the flavor of the masa.  The masa on these tamales was awesome.  I don't know how else to describe it.  The pork tamale was great too, but I'm not a fan of spicy foods and that green chile sauce was just a little hot for me to eat, but the hubster dug it.  The salad was just plain cabbage with a litlte dressing on it and it was nice to have since it cut the richness of the tamales.  The beans were good too (I think they were black beans) with the cotija cheese.  All I can do now is dream of those fantastic tamales until I return to SF.
author: Ann C.

description: this is my new favorite breakfast spot.  i have now been the past two weekends in a row and have been blown away both times by the veggie breakfast options.  the chilaquiles here are amazing and i love the chance to eat delicious oaxacan food.  today i had the best agua fresca ever: cucumber pineapple.  doesn't that sound refreshing? it was.  i haven't had a problem at all with the long line as it goes by fast and the food is ready even faster.  there is always a nice spot to eat outside and enjoy the scrumptious food.  i wish they had an actual restaurant; if so, it should be near me in the mission.
author: Kristie P.

description: Despite a long line, it moved quickly and we ordered the tostada, a tomale, and another highly recommended dish (can't remember the name, but it had the eggs). I really appreciated that they allowed us to have half-orders for the items on the menu because it allowed us to get a variety of items plus it was still more than enough food. I found the tomale to be excellent. The dough was steamed to perfection and it was perhaps the best tomale I've had in my entire life. All the ingredients in our meal was extremely fresh. The eggs were amazing, soft and melted in my mouth. I would definitely go again and try more items on the menu if I was in the ferry building on Saturday morning.
author: Will S.

description: omg, chilaquiles and tamales!  absolutely fantastic, and as good as the reviews say.  the line was pretty long, but it moves fast.  total wait time to order and get our food was probably about 20 minutes?  tasty, fresh...and to be honest mexican food is not my favorite as i normally find it too heavy for my palate.  that's not to say that primavera isn't heavy, but it sure is delicious.  it's probably better that they're only there once a week, from a health perspective, since i'd be there more than that if i could (or if i lived in the bay area any more, but just a minor detail).
author: Cynthia k.
